direction.raw_text: FAINT DAWN - 1940 (MINIATURE) Window, very small in the distance, illuminated. All around this is an almost totally black screen.  Now, as the camera moves slowly towards the window which is almost a postage stamp in the frame, other forms appear; barbed wire, cyclone fencing, and now, looming up against an early morning sky, enormous iron grille work.  Camera travels up what is now shown to be a gateway of gigantic proportions and holds on the top of it - a huge initial "K" showing darker and darker against the dawn sky.  Through this and beyond we see the fairy-tale mountaintop of Xanadu, the great castle a sillhouette as its summit, the little window a distant accent in the darkness.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: TO THE GREAT WINDOW, ALL TELLING SOMETHING OF

direction.raw_text: R TO THE GREAT WINDOW, ALL TELLING SOMETHING OF: The literally incredible domain of CHARLES FOSTER KANE. Its right flank resting for nearly forty miles on the Gulf Coast, it truly extends in all directions farther than the eye can see.  Designed by nature to be almost completely bare and flat - it was, as will develop, practically all marshland when Kane acquired and changed its face - it is now pleasantly uneven, with its fair share of rolling hills and one very good- sized mountain, all man-made.  Almost all the land is improved, either through cultivation for farming purposes of through careful landscaping, in the shape of parks and lakes.  The castle dominates itself, an enormous pile, compounded of several genuine castles, of European origin, of varying architecture - dominates the scene, from the very peak of the mountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Past which we move.  The greens are straggly and overgrown, the fairways wild with tropical weeds, the links unused and not seriously tended for a long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over a wide moat, now stagnant and choked with weeds.  We move across it and through a huge solid gateway into a formal garden, perhaps thirty yards wide and one hundred yards deep, which extends right up to the very wall of the castle.  The landscaping surrounding it has been sloppy and causal for a long time, but this particular garden has been kept up in perfect shape.  As the camera makes its way through it, towards the lighted window of the castle, there are revealed rare and exotic blooms of all kinds.  The dominating note is one of almost exaggerated tropical lushness, hanging limp and despairing.  Moss, moss, moss.  Ankor Wat, the night the last King died.

direction.raw_text: The camera pulls back, showing the whole scene to be contained in one of those glass balls which are sold in novelty stores all over the world.  A hand - Kane's hand, which has been holding the ball, relaxes.  The ball falls out of his hand and bounds down two carpeted steps leading to the bed, the camera following.  The ball falls off the last step onto the marble floor where it breaks, the fragments glittering in the first rays of the morning sun.  This ray cuts an angular pattern across the floor, suddenly crossed with a thousand bars of light as the blinds are pulled across the window. The foot of Kane's bed.  The camera very close.  Outlined against the shuttered window, we can see a form - the form of a nurse, as she pulls the sheet up over his head. dialogue.raw_text: Legendary was the Xanadu where Kubla Kahn decreed his stately pleasure dome - (with quotes in his voice) "Where twice five miles of fertile ground, with walls and towers were girdled 'round." (DROPPING THE QUOTES) Today, almost as legendary is Florida's XANADU - world's largest private pleasure ground.  Here, on the deserts of the Gulf Coast, a private mountain was commissioned, successfully built for its landlord. Here in a private valley, as in the Coleridge poem, "blossoms many an incense-bearing tree."  Verily, "a miracle of rare device."

In journalism's history, other names are honored more than Charles Foster Kane's, more justly revered.  Among publishers, second only to James Gordon Bennet the First: his dashing, expatriate son; England's Northcliffe and Beaverbrook; Chicago's Patterson and McCormick;

direction.raw_text: : A great number of headlines, set in different types and different styles, obviously from different papers, all announcing Kane's death, all appearing over photographs of Kane himself (perhaps a fifth of the headlines are in foreign languages).  An important item in connection with the headlines is that many of them - positively not all - reveal passionately conflicting opinions about Kane.  Thus, they contain variously the words "patriot," "democrat," "pacifist," "war-monger," "traitor," "idealist," "American," etc.

Great names all of them - but none of them so loved, hated, feared, so often spoken - as Charles Foster Kane. The San Francisco earthquake. First with the news were the Kane papers.  First with Relief of the Sufferers, First with the news of their Relief of the Sufferers. Kane papers scoop the world on the Armistice - publish, eight hours before competitors, complete details of the Armistice teams granted the Germans by Marshall Foch from his railroad car in the Forest of Compeigne. dialogue.raw_text: Kane's empire, in its glory, held dominion over thirty-seven newpapers, thirteen magazines, a radio network.  An empire upon an empire.  The first of grocery stores, paper mills, apartment buildings, factories, forests, ocean-liners - An empire through which for fifty years flowed, in an unending stream, the wealth of the earth's third richest gold mine...  Famed in American legend is the origin of the Kane fortune... How, to boarding housekeeper Mary Kane, by a defaulting boarder, in 1868 was left the supposedly worthless deed to an abandoned mine shaft: The Colorado Lode. The magnificent Enquirer Building of today.

dialogue.raw_text: One hundred thousand trees, twenty thousand tons of marble, are the ingredients of Xanadu's mountain. Contents of Kane's palace: paintings, pictures, statues, the very stones of many another palace, shipped to Florida from every corner of the earth, from other Kane houses, warehouses, where they mouldered for years. Enough for ten museums - the loot of the world.

dialogue.raw_text: Kane, molder of mass opinion though he was, in all his life was never granted elective office by the voters of his country.  Few U.S. news publishers have been. Few, like one-time Congressman Hearst, have ever run for any office - most know better - conclude with other political observers that one man's press has power enough for himself.  But Kane papers were once strong indeed, and once the prize seemed almost his.  In 1910, as Independent Candidate for governor, the best elements of the state behind him - the White House seemingly the next easy step in a lightning political career -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then, suddenly - less than one week before election - defeat! Shameful, ignominious - defeat that set back for twenty years the cause of reform in the U.S., forever cancelled political chances for Charles Foster Kane.  Then, in the third year of the Great Depression...  As to all publishers, it sometimes must - to Bennett, to Munsey and Hearst it did - a paper closes!  For Kane, in four short years: collapse! Eleven Kane papers, four Kane magazines merged, more sold, scrapped -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then four long years more - alone in his never-finished, already decaying, pleasure palace, aloof, seldom visited, never photographed, Charles Foster Kane continued to direct his falling empire ... vainly attempting to sway, as he once did, the destinies of a nation that has ceased to listen to him ... ceased to trust him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: :  Now begins the story proper - the seach by Thompson for the facts about Kane - his researches ... his interviews with the people who knew Kane. It is important to remember always that only at the very end of the story is Thompson himself a personality.  Until then, throughout the picture, we photograph only Thompson's back, shoulders, or his shadow - sometimes we only record his voice. He is not until the final scene a "character".  He is the personification of the search for the truth about Charles Foster Kane.  He is the investigator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As Charles Foster Kane, who has eighty-two thousand, six hundred and thirty-one shares of Metropolitan Transfer - you see, I do have a rough idea of my holdings - I sympathize with you.  Charles Foster Kane is a dangerous scoundrel, his paper should be run out of town and a committee should be formed to boycott him.  You may, if you can form such a committee, put me down for a contribution of one thousand dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Charles, my time is too valuable for me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the other hand - (his manner becomes serious) I am the publisher of the Enquirer. As such, it is my duty - I'll let you in on a little secret, it is also my pleasure - to see to it that decent, hard-working people of this city are not robbed blind by a group of money - mad pirates because, God help them, they have no one to look after their interests!  I'll let you in on another little secret, Mr. Thatcher. I think I'm the man to do it.  You see, I have money and property -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I don't defend the interests of the underprivileged, somebody else will - maybe somebody without any money or any property and that would be too bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know how to tap, Mr. Thatcher?  You ought to learn - (humming quietly, he continues to dance)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I happened to see your consolidated statement yesterday, Charles. Could I not suggest to you that it is unwise for you to continue this philanthropic enterprise - (sneeringly) this Enquirer - that is costing you one million dollars a year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right.  We did lose a million dollars last year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We expect to lost a million next year, too.  You know, Mr. Thatcher - (starts tapping quietly) at the rate of a million a year - we'll have to close this place in sixty years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thompson - at the desk.  With a gesture of annoyance, he is closing the manuscript. Camera arcs quickly around from over his shoulder to hold on door behind him, missing his face as he rises and turns to confront Miss Anderson, who has come into the room to shoo him out.  Very prominent on this wall is an over-sized oil painting of Thatcher in the best Union League Club renaissance style.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his hat on his head and starts out, lighting a cigarette as he goes.  Miss Anderson, scandalized, watches him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You have enjoyed a very rare privilege, young man.  Did you find what you were looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  Tell me something, Miss Anderson.  You're not Rosebud, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't think you were.  Well, thanks for the use of the hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Closeup of a still of Kane, aged about sixty-five.  Camera pulls back, showing it is a framed photograph on the wall. Over the picture are crossed American flags.  Under it sits Bernstein, back of his desk.  Bernstein, always an undersized Jew, now seems even smaller than in his youth.  He is bald as an egg, spry, with remarkably intense eyes.  As camera continues to travel back, the back of Thompson's head and his shoulders come into the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein looks out of the window and keeps on looking, seeming to see something as he talks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (wryly) Who's a busy man?  Me?  I'm Chairman of the Board.  I got nothing but time ...  What do you want to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still explaining) Well, Mr. Bernstein, you were with Mr.  Kane from the very beginning -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From before the beginning, young fellow.  And now it's after the end. (turns to Thompson) Anything you want to know about him - about the paper -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: -  We thought maybe, if we can find out what he meant by that last word - as he was dying -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Rosebud?  Maybe some girl? There were a lot of them back in the early days, and -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not some girl he knew casually and then remembered after fifty years, on his death bed -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're pretty young, Mr. - (remembers the name) Mr. Thompson.  A fellow will remember things you wouldn't think he'd remember.  You take me.  One day, back in 1896, I was crossing over to Jersey on a ferry and as we pulled out, there was another ferry pulling in - (slowly) - and on it, there was a girl waiting to get off.  A white dress she had on - and she was carrying a white pastrol - and I only saw her for one second and she didn't see me at all - but I'll bet a month hasn't gone by since that I haven't thought of that girl. (triumphantly) See what I mean? (smiles) Well, so what are you doing about this "Rosebud," Mr. Thompson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm calling on people who knew Mr. Kane.  I'm calling on you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who else you been to see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I went down to Atlantic City -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susie?  I called her myself the day after he died.  I thought maybe somebody ought to... (sadly) She couldn't even come to the 'phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know why?  She was so -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going back there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who else did you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody else, but I've been through that stuff of Walter Thatcher's. That journal of his -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thatcher!  That man was the biggest darn fool I ever met -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He made an awful lot of money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not trick to make an awful lot of money if all you want is to make a lot of money. (his eyes get reflective) Thatcher!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He never knew there was anything in the world but money.  That kind of fellow you can fool every day in the week - and twice on Sundays! (reflectively) The time he came to Rome for Mr. Kane's twenty-fifth birthday... You know, when Mr. Kane got control of his own money...  Such a fool like Thatcher - I tell you, nobody's business!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Bernstein speaking to Thompson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves the sentence up in the air, as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He knew what he wanted, Mr. Kane did, and he got it!  Thatcher never did figure him out.  He was hard to figure sometimes, even for me. Mr. Kane was a genius like he said. He had that funny sense of humor. Sometimes even I didn't get the joke.  Like that night the opera house of his opened in Chicago... You know, the opera house he built for Susie, she should be an opera singer... (indicates with a little wave of his hand what he thinks of that; sighing) That was years later, of course - 1914 it was.  Mrs. Kane took the leading part in the opera, and she was terrible.  But nobody had the nerve to say so - not even the critics.  Mr. Kane was a big man in those days.  But this one fellow, this friend of his, Branford Leland -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - It is late.  The room is almost empty.  Nobody is at work at the desks.  Bernstein, fifty, is waiting anxiously with a little group of Kane's hirelings, most of them in evening dress with overcoats and hats.  Eveybody is tense and expectant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody behind Bernstein has trouble concealing his laughter. The City Editor speaks quickly to cover the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein turns. Medium long shot of Kane, now forty-nine, already quite stout. He is in white tie, wearing his overcoat and carrying a folded opera hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Hirelings rush, with Bernstein, to Kane's side.  Widespread, half-suppressed sensation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody falls silent.  There isn't anything to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at him for a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Hireling indicates the closed glass door of a little office at the other end of the City Room.  Kane takes it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane crosses the length of the long City Room to the glass door indicated before by the Hireling.  The City Editor looks at Bernstein.  Kane opens the door and goes into the office, closing the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (turns to a young hireling; quietly) What about Branford Leland?  Has he got in his copy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go in and ask him to hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, why don't you, Mr. Bernstein? You know Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at him for a moment; then slowly) I might make him nervous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) You and Leland and Mr. Kane - you were great friends back in the old days, I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a smile) That's right.  They called us the "Three Musketeers."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a great guy - Leland. (another little pause) Why'd he ever leave New York?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he isn't saying) That's a long story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a tactless one) Wasn't there some sort of quarrel between -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) I had nothing to do with it. (then, somberly) It was Leland and Mr. Kane, and you couldn't call it a quarrel exactly.  Better we should forget such things - (turning to City Editor) Leland is writing it up from the dramatic angle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  I thought it was a good idea. We've covered it from the news end, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the social.  How about the music notice?  You got that in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, it's already made up. Our Mr. Mervin wrote a small review.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enthusiastic?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, very! (quietly) Naturally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well - isn't that nice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bernstein -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Kane, this is a surprise!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got a nice plant here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was the show covered by every department?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly according to your instructions, Mr. Kane.  We've got two spreads of pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very, very casually) And the notice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes - Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Is it good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there's another one still to come - the dramatic notice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) It isn't finished?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's Leland, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Has he said when he'll finish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We haven't heard from him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He used to work fast - didn't he, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sure did, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right in there, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (helpless, but very concerned)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . KANE -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right, Mr. Bernstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leland and Mr. Kane - they haven't spoke together for ten years. (long pause; finally) Excuse me. (starts toward the door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Bernstein comes in.  An empty bottle is standing on Leland's desk.  He has fallen over his typewriter, his face on the keys. A sheet of paper is in the machine.  A paragraph has been typed. Kane is standing at the other side of the desk looking down on him.  This is the first time we see murder in Kane's face. Bernstein looks at Kane, then crosses to Leland.  He shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein looks over nearsightedly, painfully reading the paragraph written on the page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein looks at Kane for a moment, then looks back, tortured.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane snatches the paper from the roller and reads it for himself.  Slowly, a queer look comes over his face.  Then he speaks, very quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein retreats from the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Brad!  Brad! (he straightens, looks at Kane; pause) He ain't been drinking before, Mr. Kane.  Never.  We would have heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally; after a pause) What does it say there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he written?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "Miss Susan Alexander, a pretty but hopelessly incompetent amateur - (he waits for a minute to catch his breath; he doesn't like it) - last night opened the new Chicago Opera House in a performance of - of -" (looks up miserably) I can't pronounce that name, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thais.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading again) "Her singing, happily, is no concern of this department.  Of her acting, it is absolutely impossible to..." (he continues to stare at the page)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a short silence) Go on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without looking up) That's all there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of her acting, it is absolutely impossible to say anything except that it represents a new low... (then sharply) Have you got that, Mr. Bernstein? In the opinion of this reviewer -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (miserably) I didn't see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't here, Mr. Bernstein.  I'm dictating it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at him) I can't take shorthand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get me a typewriter.  I'll finish the notice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Long shot of Kane in his shirt sleeves, illuminated by a desk light, typing furiously.  As the camera starts to pull even farther away from this, and as Bernstein - as narrator - begins to speak -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - Bernstein speaking to Thompson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On these last words, we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He finished it.  He wrote the worst notice I ever read about the girl he loved.  We ran it in every paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I guess Mr. Kane didn't think so well of Susie's art anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at him very soberly) He thought she was great, Mr. Thompson.  He really believed that. He put all his ambition on that girl.  After she came along, he never really cared for himself like he used to.  Oh, I don't blame Susie -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, how could he write that roast?  The notices in the Kane papers were always very kind to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.  He saw to that.  I tell you, Mr. Thompson, he was a hard man to figure out.  He had that funny sense of humor.  And then, too, maybe he thought by finishing that piece he could show Leland he was an honest man.  You see, Leland didn't think so.  I guess he showed him all right.  He's a nice fellow, but he's a dreamer.  They were always together in those early days when we just started the Enquirer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - The front half of the second floor constitutes one large City Room.  Despite the brilliant sunshine outside, very little of it is actually getting into the room because the windows are small and narrow.  There are about a dozen tables and desks, of the old-fashioned type, not flat, available for reporters. Two tables, on a raised platform at the end of the room, obviously serve the city room executives.  To the left of the platform is an open door which leads into the Sanctrum. As Kane and Leland enter the room, an elderly, stout gent on the raised platform, strikes a bell and the other eight occupants of the room - all men - rise and face the new arrivals.  Carter, the elderly gent, in formal clothes, rises and starts toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are following Carter to his raised platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a terrific crash at the doorway.  They all turn to see Bernstein sprawled at the entrance.  A roll of bedding, a suitcase, and two framed pictures were too much for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein rises and comes over, tidying himself as he comes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The delivery wagon driver has now appeared in the entrance with parts of the bedstead and other furniture.  He is looking about, a bit bewildered.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome, Mr. Kane, to the "Enquirer."  I am Herbert Carter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Mr Carter.  This is Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bowing) How do you do, Mr. Leland?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the standing reporters) Are they standing for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it would be a nice gesture the new publisher -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Ask them to sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may resume your work, gentlemen. (to Kane) I didn't know your plans and so I was unable to make any preparations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't my plans myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a matter of fact, I haven't got any.  Except to get out a newspaper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you would come here a moment, please, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Carter, this is Mr. Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein is my general manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frigidly) How do you do, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a private office here, haven't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating open door to left of platform) My little sanctum is at your disposal.  But I don't think I understand -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to live right here. (reflectively) As long as I have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But a morning newspaper, Mr. Kane. After all, we're practically closed twelve hours a day - except for the business offices -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's one of the things I think must be changed, Mr. Carter.  The news goes on for twenty-four hours a day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE DAY - Kane, in his shirt sleeves, at a roll-top desk in the Sanctum, is working feverishly on copy and eating a very sizeable meal at the same time.  Carter, still formally coated, is seated alongside him.  Leland, seated in a corner, is looking on, detached, amused.  The furniture has been pushed around and Kane's effects are somewhat in place.  On a corner of the desk, Bernstein is writing down figures.  No one pays any attention to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane has finished eating.  He pushes away his plates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loudly, so that the neighbors can hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane isn't listening to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein looks up from his figures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at Leland with a fond nod of his head at Bernstein. Leland grins back.  Mr. Carter, meantime, has risen stiffly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter, with a look that runs just short of apoplexy, leaves the room, closing the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein lifts his head and looks at Kane.  Kane gazes back at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not criticizing, Mr. Carter, but here's what I mean.  There's a front page story in the "Chronicle," (points to it) and a picture - of a woman in Brooklyn who is missing.  Probably murdered. (looks to make sure of the name) A Mrs. Harry Silverstone.  Why didn't the "Enquirer" have that this morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffly) Because we're running a newspaper, Mr.  Kane, not a scandal sheet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm still hungry, Brad.  Let's go to Rector's and get something decent. (pointing to the "Chronicle" before him) The "Chronicle" has a two-column headline, Mr. Carter.  Why haven't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no news big enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If the headline is big enough, it makes the new big enough.  The murder of Mrs. Harry Silverstone -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hotly) As a matter of fact, we sent a man to the Silverstone home yesterday afternoon. (triumphantly) Our man even arrived before the "Chronicle" reporter.  And there's no proof that the woman was murdered - or even that she's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling a bit) The "Chronicle" doesn't say she's murdered, Mr. Carter.  It says the neighbors are getting suspicious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffly) It's not our function to report the gossip of housewives.  If we were interested in that kind of thing, Mr. Kane, we could fill the paper twice over daily -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) That's the kind of thing we are going to be interested in from now on, Mr. Carter.  Right now, I wish you'd send your best man up to see Mr. Silverstone.  Have him tell Mr.  Silverstone if he doesn't produce his wife at once, the "Enquirer" will have him arrested. (he gets an idea) Have him tell Mr. Silverstone he's a detective from the Central Office. If Mr. Silverstone asks to see his badge, your man is to get indignant and call Mr. Silverstone an anarchist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really, Mr. Kane, I can't see the function of a respectable newspaper -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've just made a shocking discovery. The "Enquirer" is without a telephone.  Have two installed at once!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ordered six already this morning! Got a discount!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Mr. Kane -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll be all today, Mr. Carter. You've been most understanding. Good day, Mr. Carter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor Mr. Carter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head) What makes those fellows think that a newspaper is something rigid, something inflexible, that people are supposed to pay two cents for -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without looking up) Three cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Two cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tapping on the paper) This is all figured at three cents a copy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Re-figure it, Mr. Bernstein, at two cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs and puts papers in his pocket) All right, but I'll keep these figures, too, just in case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ready for dinner, Brad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Leland, if Mr. Kane, he should decide to drop the price to one cent, or maybe even he should make up his mind to give the paper away with a half-pound of tea - you'll just hold him until I get back, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not guaranteeing a thing, Mr. Bernstein.  You people work too fast for me!  Talk about new brooms!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who said anything about brooms?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a saying, Mr. Bernstein.  A new broom sweeps clean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The ground floor witht he windows on the street - of the "Enquirer."  It is almost midnight by an old-fashioned clock on the wall.  Grouped around a large table, on which are several locked forms of type, very old-fashioned of course, but true to the period - are Kane and Leland in elegant evening clothes, Bernstein, unchanged from the afternoon, and Smathers, the composing room foreman, nervous and harassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane turns his back on him, speaks again to the composing room foreman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane sighs, unperturbed, as he reaches out his hand and shoves the forms off the table onto the floor, where they scatter into hundreds of bits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smather's mouth opens wider and wider.  Bradford and Bernstein are grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts out of the room, followed by Leland.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But it's impossible, Mr. Kane.  We can't remake these pages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These pages aren't made up as I want them, Mr. Smathers.  We go to press in five minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (about to crack up) The "Enquirer" has an old and honored tradition, Mr. Kane... The "Enquirer" is not in competition with those other rags.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We should be publishing such rags, that's all I wish.  Why, the "Enquirer" - I wouldn't wrap up the liver for the cat in the "Enquirer" -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enraged) Mr. Kane, I must ask you to see to it that this - this person learns to control his tongue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been a newspaperman my whole life and I don't intend - (he starts to sputter) - if it's your intention that I should continue to be harassed by this - this - (he's really sore) I warn you, Mr. Kane, it would go against my grain to desert you when you need me so badly - but I would feel obliged to ask that my resignation be accepted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is accepted, Mr. Carter, with assurances of my deepest regard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Mr. Kane, I meant -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Let's remake these pages, Mr. Smathers.  We'll have to publish a half hour late, that's all.

dialogue.raw_text: You can remake them now, can't you, Mr. Smathers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After the types 've been reset and the pages have been remade according to the way I told you before, Mr. Smathers, kindly have proofs pulled and bring them to me.  Then, if I can't find any way to improve them again - (almost as if reluctantly) - I suppose we'll have to go to press.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Smathers) In case you don't understand, Mr. Smathers - he's a new broom.

direction.raw_text: VERY EARLY DAWN - The picture is mainly occupied by a large building, on the roof of which the lights spell out the word "Enquirer" against the sunrise.  We do not see the street or the first few stories of this building, the windows of which would be certainly illuminated.  What we do see is the floor on which is located the City Room.  Over this scene, newboys are heard selling the Chronicle, their voices growing in volume. As the dissolve complete itself, camera moves toward the one lighted window - the window of the Sanctrum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VERY EARLY DAWN - The newsboys are still heard from the street below - fainter but very insistent. Kane's office is gas-lit, of course, as is the rest of the Enquirer building. Kane, in his shirt sleeves, stands at the open window looking out.  The bed is already made up.  On it is seated Bernstein, smoking the end of a cigar.  Leland is in a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane, taking a deep breath of the morning air, closes the window and turns to the others.  The voices of the newsboys, naturally, are very much fainter after this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland rises from the chair, stretching painfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at him for a minute with a queer smile of happy concentration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane grabs a piece of rough paper and a grease crayon.  Sitting down on the bed next to Bernstein, he starts to write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Leland for a minute and goes back to his writing, reading as he writes. Bernstein has risen and crossed to one side of Kane.  They both stand looking out.  Leland joins him on the other side. Their three heads are silhouetted against the sky.  Leland's head is seen to turn slightly as he looks into Kane's face - camera very close on this - Kane turns to him and we know their eyes have met, although their faces are almost in sillhouette. Bernstein is still smoking a cigar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: !  CHRONICLE!  H'YA - THE CHRONICLE - GET YA!  CHRONICLE!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll be on the street soon, Charlie - another ten minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at his watch) It's three hours and fifty minutes late - but we did it -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tired?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's been a tough day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A wasted day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Wasted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulously) Charlie?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just made the paper over four times today, Mr. Kane.  That's all -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've changed the front page a little, Mr. Bernstein.  That's not enough - There's something I've got to get into this paper besides pictures and print -  I've got to make the "New York Enquirer" as important to New York as the gas in that light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) What're you going to do, Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My Declaration of Principles - (he says it with quotes around it) Don't smile, Brad - (getting the idea) Take dictation, Mr. Bernstein -

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he writes) These'll be kept. (stops for a minute and reads what he has written; reading) I'll provide the people of this city with a daily paper that will tell all the news honestly. (starts to write again; reading as he writes) will also provide them -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the second sentence you've started with "I" -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) People are going to know who's responsible.  And they're going to get the news - the true news - quickly and simply and entertainingly. (he speaks with real conviction) And no special interests will be allowed to interfere with the truth of that news.

direction.raw_text: - CIRCULATION 26,000" passes through foreground, and we wipe to: A pile of "Enquirers" for sale on a broken down wooden box on a street corner, obviously a poor district.  A couple of coins fall on the pile. The stoop of a period door with old-fashioned enamel milk can and a bag of rolls.  Across the sidewalk before this, moves the shadow of an old-fashioned bicycle with an enormous front wheel.  A copy of the "Enquirer" is tossed on the stoop. A breakfast table - beautiful linen and beautiful silver - everything very expensive, gleaming in the sunshine.  Into a silver newspaper rack there is slipped a copy of the "Enquirer". Here, as before, the boxed editorial reading MY PRINCIPLES - A DECLARATION BY CHARLES FOSTER KANE, is very prominent on the front page. The wooden floor of a railroad station, flashing light and dark as a train behind the camera rushes by.  On the floor, there is tossed a bound bundle of the "New York Enquirer" - the Declaration of Principles still prominent. Rural Delivery - a copy of the "Enquirer"s being put into bins, showing state distribution. The railroad platform again.  We stay here for four images. On each image, the speed of the train is faster and the piles of the "Enquirer" are larger.  On the first image, we move in to hold on the words "CIRCULATION - 31,000."  We are this close for the next pile which reads 40,000; the next one which reads 55,000, and the last which is 62,000.  In each instance, the bundles of newspapers are thicker and the speed of the moving train behind the camera is increased. The entire montage above indicated is accompanied by a descriptive complement of sound - the traffic noises of New York in the 1890's; wheels on cobblestones and horses' hooves; bicycle bells; the mooning of cattle and the crowing of roosters (in the RFD shot), and in all cases where the railroad platform is used - the mounting sound of the railroad train. The last figure "62,000" opposite the word "CIRCULATION" on the "Enquirer" masthead changes to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera continues to travel down to sidewalk in front of the Chronicle office.  The Chronicle office has a plateglass window in which is reflected traffic moving up and down the street, also the figures of Kane, Leland and Bernstein, who are munching peanuts. Inside the window, almost filling it, is a large photograph of the "Chronicle" staff, with Reilly prominently seated in the center.  A sign over the photo reads: EDITORIAL AND EXECUTIVE STAFF OF THE NEW YORK CHRONICLE.  A sign beneath it reads: GREATEST NEWSPAPER STAFF IN THE WORLD.  The sign also includes the "Chronicle" circulation figure.  There are nine men in the photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane, smiling, lights a cigarette, at the same time looking into the window.  Camera moves in to hold on the photograph of nine men, still holding the reflection of Kane's smiling face.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: READ THE ENQUIRER AMERICA'S FINEST CIRCULATION 62,000

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up at the sign - happily) Sixty-two thousand -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That looks pretty nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating the Chronicle Building) Let's hope they like it there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From the Chronicle Building that sign is the biggest thing you can see - every floor guaranteed - let's hope it bothers them - it cost us enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the sign over the photograph in the window) Look at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The "Chronicle" is a good newspaper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a good idea for a newspaper. (reading the figures) Four hundred sixy thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, with them fellows - (referring to the photo) - it's no trick to get circulation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, Mr. Bernstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) You know how long it took the "Chronicle" to get that staff together?  Twenty years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Nine men, arrayed as in the photograph, but with Kane beaming in the center of the first row.  The men, variously with mustaches, beards, bald heads, etc. are easily identified as being the same men, Reilly prominent amongst them. As camera pulls back, it is revealed that they are being photographed - by an old-type professional photographer, big box, black hood and all - in a corner of the room.  It is 1:30 at night.  Desks, etc. have been pushed against the wall. Running down the center of the room is a long banquet table, at which twenty diners have finished their meals.  The eleven remaining at their seats - these include Bernstein and Leland - are amusedly watching the photographic ceremonies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The photographic subjects rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckling and beaming, he makes his way to his place at the head of the table.  The others have already sat down.  Kane gets his guests' attention by rapping on the table with a knife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his two fingers in his mouth and lets out a shrill whistle.  This is a signal.  A band strikes up a lively ditty of the period and enters in advance a regiment of very magnificent maidens, as daringly arrayed as possible in the chorus costumes of the day.  The rest of this episode will be planned and staged later.  Its essence is that Kane is just a healthy and happy young man having a wonderful time. As some of the girls are detached from the line and made into partners for individual dancing -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's all.  Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a sudden thought) Make up an extra copy and mail it to the "Chronicle."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen of the "Enquirer"!  This has, I think, been a fitting welcome to those distinguished journalists - (indicates the eight men) Mr. Reilly in particular - who are the latest additions to our ranks. It will make them happy to learn that the "Enquirer's" circulation this morning passed the two hundred thousand mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two hundred and one thousand, six hundred and forty-seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of you - new and old -  You're all getting the best salaries in town.  Not one of you has been hired because of his loyalty. It's your talent I'm interested in.  That talent that's going to make the "Enquirer" the kind of paper I want - the best newspaper in the world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: However, I think you'll agree we've heard enough about newspapers and the newspaper business for one night.  There are other subjects in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : A montage of various scenes, between the years 1891-1900. The scenes indicate the growth of the "Enquirer" under the impulse of Kane's personal drive.  Kane is shown, thus, at various activities: Move down from the sign: READ THE ENQUIRER  GREATEST STAFF IN THE WORLD to street in front of saloon with parade passing (boys going off to the Spanish-American War)-  A torchlight parade with the torches reflected in the glass window of the saloon - the sound of brass band playing "It's a Hot Time." In the window of the saloon is a large sign or poster "REMEMBER THE MAINE" INSERT:  Remington drawing of American boys, similar to the parade above, in which "Our Boys" in the expeditionary hats are seen marching off to war. Back of observation car.  Shot of Kane congratulating Teddy Roosevelt (the same shot as in the News Digest - without flickering). The wooden floor of the railroad platform again - a bundle of "Enquirers" - this time an enormous bundle - is thrown down, and the moving shadows of the train behind the camera indicate that it is going like a bat out of hell.  A reproduction of Kane and Teddy shaking hands as above is very prominent in the frame and almost hogs the entire front page.  The headline indicates the surrender of Cuba.
direction.name: direction

The photographers take pictures with a mighty flash of old-fashioned flash powder.  The condemned man in the foreground (in silhouette) is startled by this. A cup of coffee and a doughnut are on the newspaper, and a servant girl - over whose shoulder we see the paper - is stirring the coffee. The Beaux Art Ball.  A number of elderly swells are jammed into a hallway.  Servants suddenly divest them of their furs, overcoats and wraps, revealing them to be in fancy dress costume, pink fleshings, etc., the effect to be very surprising, very lavish and very very ridiculous.  We see, among others, Mr. Thatcher himself (as Ben Hur) ribbon around, his bald head and all.  At the conclusion of this tableau, the image freezes and we pull back to show it reproduced on the society page of the "New York Enquirer." Over the "Enquirer"'s pictorial version of the Beaux Art Ball is thrown a huge fish - then coffee grounds - altogether a pretty repulsive sight. direction.raw_text: DAY - The whole floor is now a City Room.  It is twice its former size, yet not too large for all the desks and the people using them.  The windows have been enlarged, providing a good deal more light and air.  A wall calendar says September 9th. Kane and Bernstein enter and stand in the entrance a moment. Kane, who really did look a bit peaked before, is now clear- eyed and tanned.  He is wearing new English clothes.  As they come into the room, Bernstein practically walking sideways, is doing nothing but beaming and admiring Kane, quelling like a mother at the Carnegie Hall debut of her son.  Seeing and recognizing Kane, the entire staff rises to its feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The order is immediately obeyed, everybody going into business of feverish activity.
