direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A girl like that, believe me, she's lucky!  Presiden't niece, huh! Say, before he's through, she'll be a Presiden't wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Bernstein and Thompson.  As the dissolve comes, Bernstein's voice is heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The way things turned out, I don't need to tell you - Miss Emily Norton was no rosebud!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't end very well, did it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) It ended - (a slight pause) Then there was Susie - that ended, too. (shrugs, a pause; then looking up into Thompson's eyes) guess he didn't make her very happy - (A PAUSE) You know, I was thinking - that Rosebud you're trying to find out about -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe that was something he lost. Mr. Kane was a man that lost - almost everything he had - (a pause) You ought to talk to Bradford Leland.  He could tell you a lot. I wish I could tell you where Leland is, but I don't know myself.  He may be out of town somewhere - he may be dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In case you'd like to know, Mr. Bernstein, he's at the Huntington Memorial Hospital on 180th Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't say!  Why I had no idea -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing particular the matter with him, they tell me.  Just - (controls himself)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just old age. (smiles sadly) It's the only disease, Mr. Thompson, you don't look forward to being cured of. (pauses) You ought to see Mr. Leland. There's a whole lot of things he could tell you - if he wanted to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Close shot - Thompson.  He is tilted back in a chair which seems to be, and is, leaning against a chimney.  Leland's voice is heard for a few moments before Leland is seen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera has pulled back, during above speech, revealing that Leland, wrapped in a blanket, is in a wheel chair, talking to Thompson.  They are on the flat roof of a hospital.  Other people in wheel chairs can be seen in the background, along with a nurse or two.  They are all sunning themselves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you get to my age, young man, you don't miss anything.  Unless maybe it's a good drink of bourbon. Even that doesn't make much difference, if you remember there hasn't been any good bourbon in this country for twenty years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Leland, you were -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't happen to have a cigar, do you?  I've got a young physician - must remember to ask to see his license - the odds are a hundred to one he hasn't got one - who thinks I'm going to stop smoking... I changed the subject, didn't I? Dear, dear!  What a disagreeable old man I've become.  You want to know what I think of Charlie Kane? Well - I suppose he has some private sort of greatness.  But he kept it to himself. (grinning) He never - gave himself away -  He never gave anything away.  He just - left you a tip.  He had a generous mind.  I don't suppose anybody ever had so many opinions.  That was because he had the power to express them, and Charlie lived on power and the excitement of using it -  But he didn't believe in anything except Charlie Kane.  He never had a conviction in his life. I guess he died without one - That must have been pretty unpleasant.  Of course, a lot of us check out with no special conviction about death.  But we do know what we're leaving ... we believe in something. (looks sharply at Thompson) You're absolutely sure you haven't got a cigar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind -  Bernstein told you about the first days at the office, didn't he?  Well, Charlie was a bad newspaper man even then.  He entertained his readers, but he never told them the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you could remember something that -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can remember everything.  That's my curse, young man.  It's the greatest curse that's ever been inflicted on the human race.  Memory - I was his oldest friend. (slowly) As far as I was concerned, he behaved like swine.  Maybe I wasnt' his friend.  If I wasn't, he never had one.  Maybe I was what nowadays you call a stooge -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The party (previously shown in the Bernstein sequence). We start this sequence toward the end of the former one, but from a fresh angle, holding on Leland, who is at the end of the table.  Kane is heard off, making a speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause.  During above, Bernstein has come to Leland's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His tone causes Bernstein to look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The above speeches are heard under the following dialogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane whistles.  The band and the chorus girls enter and hell breaks loose all around Leland and Bernstein.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane has come up to Leland and Bernstein.  He sits down next to them, lighting a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Georgie, a very handsome madam has walked into the picture, stands behind him.  She leans over and speaks quietly in his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland shudders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not one of you has been hired because of his loyalty.  It's your talent I'm interested in.  That talent that's going to make the "Enquirer" the kind of paper I want - the best newspaper in the world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it wonderful?  Such a party!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: However, I think you'll agree we've heard enough about newspapers and the newspaper business for one night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Leland) What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bernstein, these men who are now with the "Enquirer" - who were with the "Chronicle" until yesterday - weren't they just as devoted to the "Chronicle" kind of paper as they are now to - our kind of paper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.  They're like anybody else. They got work to do.  They do it. (proudly) Only they happen to be the best men in the business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing his speech) There are other subjects in the world -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a minute) Do we stand for the same things that the "Chronicle" stands for, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) Certainly not.  So what's that got to do with it?  Mr. Kane, he'll have them changed to his kind of newspapermen in a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably.  There's always a chance, of course, that they'll change Mr. Kane - without his knowing it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, gentlemen, are we going to war?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our readers are, anyway, I don't know about the rest of the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enthusiastically) It'll be our first foreign war in fifty years, Brad.  We'll cover it the way the "Hickville Gazette" covers the church social!  The names of everybody there; what they wore; what they ate; who won the prizes; who gave the prizes - (gets excited) I tell you, Brad, I envy you. (quoting) By Bradford Leland, the "Enquirer's" Special Correspondent at the Front. I'm almost tempted -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there is no Front, Charlie. There's a very doubtful civil war. Besides, I don't want the job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Brad, all right - you don't have to be a war correspondent unless you want to - I'd want to. (looking up) Hello, Georgie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is everything the way you want it, dear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) If everybody's having fun, that's the way I want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got some other little girls coming over -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Charles, I tell you there is no war!  There's a condition that should be remedied - but between that and a -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seriously) How would the "Enquirer" look with no news about this non-existent war - with Benton, Pulitzer and Heart devoting twenty columns a day to it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do it only because you do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) And I do it because they do it, and they do it - it's a vicious circle, isn't it? (rises) I'm going over to Georgie's, Brad - you know, Georgie, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over Kane's next lines) Glad to meet you, Brad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you about Brad, Georgie. He needs to relax.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some ships with wonderful wines have managed to slip through the enemy fleet that's blockading New York harbor - (grins) Georgie knows a young lady whom I'm sure you'd adore - wouldn't he, Georgie?  Why only the other evening I said to myself, if Brad were only here to adore this young lady - this - (snaps his fingers) What's her name again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGIE'S PLACE - NIGHT - Georgie is introducing a young lady to Branford Leland.  On sound track we hear piano music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera pans to include Kane, seated at piano, with girls gathered around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane has broken into "Oh, Mr. Kane!" and Charlie and the girls start to sing.  Ethel leads the unhappy Leland over to the group.  Kane, seeing Leland and taking his eye, motions to the professor who has been standing next to him to take over.  The professor does so.  The singing continues.  Kane rises and crosses to Leland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane starts quietly to dance in time to the music.  Leland smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (right on cue from preceding scene) Ethel - this gentlemen has been very anxious to meet you -  This is Ethel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie!  Play the song about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there a song about Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, Brad. (draws him slightly aside) I've got an idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean I've got a job for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to be a war correspondent - how about being a dramatic critic?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sincerely, but not gushing; seriously) I'd like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You start tomorrow night.  Richard Carl in "The Spring Chicken." (or supply show) I'll get us some girls.  You get tickets.  A drama critic gets them free, you know. (grins) Rector's at seven?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still smiling) It doesn't make any difference about me, but one of these days you're going to find out that all this charm of yours won't be enough -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (has stopped dancing) You're wrong.  It does make a difference to you -  Rector's, Brad? (starts to dance again) Come to think of it, I don't blame you for not wanting to be a war correspondent.  You won't miss anything.  It isn't much of a war. Besides, they tell me there isn't a decent restaurant on the whole island.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Leland, Kane, two young ladies at Rector's.  Popular music is heard over the soundtrack.  Everybody is laughing very, very hard at something Kane has said.  The girls are hysterical. Kane can hardly breathe.  As Leland's laughter becomes more and more hearty, it only increases the laughter of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - As told by Bernstein.  Kane is calling down to Leland and Bernstein (as before).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A band on deck strikes up "Auld Lang Syne" and further ship-to- shore conversation is rendered unfeasible. Bernstein and Leland on deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slight pause.  They continue on their way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This stops Bernstein.  Bernstein looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland is surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses.  "Auld Lang Syne" can still be heard from the deck of the department steamer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland puts his hand in his pocket, pulls out a pencil and small engagement book, opens the book and starts to write. Leland's pencil writing on a page in the engagement book open to September 9: "Rector's - 8:30 p.m."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Front page "Enquirer."  Large picture of the young couple - Kane and Emily - occupying four columns - very happy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't expect me to keep any of those promises, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns to Leland) Do you, Mr. Leland?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Certainly not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Leland, why didn't you go to Europe with him?  He wanted you to.  He said to me just yesterday -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted him to have fun - and with me along -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bernstein, I wish you'd let me ask you a few questions, and answer me truthfully.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't I always?  Most of the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bernstein, am I a stuffed shirt? Am I a horse-faced hypocrite?  Am I a New England school-marm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you thought I'd answer different from what Mr. Kane tells you - well, I wouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (good naturedly) You're in a conspiracy against me, you two.  You always have been.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Against me there should be such a conspiracy some time!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a hopeful look in his eyes) Well, he'll be coming back in September.  The Majestic.  I got the reservations.  It gets in on the ninth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: September the ninth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Leland and Thompson.  Leland is speaking as we dissolve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson had handed Leland a paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has authorized me to state on previous occasions that she regards their brief marriage as a distateful episode in her life that she prefers to forget.  With assurances of the highest esteem - Leland hands the paper back to Thompson.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I used to go to dancing school with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a letter from her lawyers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading aloud from the letter) David, Grobleski & Davis -  My dear Rawlston - (looks up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rawlston is my boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.  I know about Mr. Rawlston.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows the first Mrs. Kane socially -  That's the answer we got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) I am in receipt of your favor of yesterday.  I beg you to do me the courtesy of accepting my assurance that Mrs. Whitehall cannot be induced to contribute any more information on the career of Charles Foster Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brief marriage!  Ten years! (sighs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was he in love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He married for love - (a little laugh) That's why he did everything. That's why he went into politics. It seems we weren't enough.  He wanted all the voters to love him, too.  All he really wanted out of life was love.  That's Charlie's story - it's the story of how he lost it.  You see, he just didn't have any to give.  He loved Charlie Kane, of course, very dearly - and his mother, I guess he always loved her.  As for Emily - well, all I can tell you is Emily's story as she told it to me, which probably isn't fair - there's supposed to be two sides to every story - and I guess there are.  I guess there's more than two sides -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Newspaper - Kane's marriage to Emily with still of group on White House lawn, same setup as early newsreel in News Digest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Screaming headline: OIL SCANDAL! DISSOLVE: Headline reading: KANE TO SEE PRESIDENT DISSOLVE: Big headline on "Enquirer" front page which reads: KANE TO SEE PRESIDENT Under this, one of those big box signed editorials, typical of Kane, illustrated, on subject of the power of the president, expressed in about nine different cases of type, and illustrated by a cartoon of the White House, on which camera tightens, as we - DISSOLVE OUT:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - This scene is shot so as never to show the President - or at least never his face.  There is present the President's Secretary, sitting on one side of the desk, intently taking notes.  Kane is on his feet, in front of the desk, tense and glaring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Secretary rises.  Kane, with every bit of will power remotely at his disposal to control what might become an hysterical outburst, manages to bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts out of the office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is the unanimous opinion of my Cabinent - in which I concur - that the proposed leases are in the best interests of the Governement and the people. (pauses) You are not, I hope, suggesting that these interests are not indentical?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not suggesting anything, Mr. President!  I've come here to tell you that, unless some action is taken promptly - and you are the only one who can take it - the oil that is the property of the people of this country will be turned over for a song to a gang of high- pressure crooks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) I must refuse to allow you to continue in this vein, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) It's the only vein I know.  I tell the facts the way I see them.  And any man that knows that facts -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know the facts, Mr. Kane.  And I happen to have the incredible insolence to differ with you as to what they mean. (pause) You're a man of great talents, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand that you have political ambitions.  Unfortunately, you seem incapable of allowing any other opinion but your own -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (building to a frenzy) I'm much obliged, Mr. President, for your concern about me.  However, I happen to be concerned at this moment with the matter of extensive oil lands belonging to the people of the United States, and I say that if this lease goes through, the property of the people of the United States goes into the hands of -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) You've made your point perfectly clear, Mr. Kane.  Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Kane, Reilly, Leland and a composing room Foreman, in working clothes, bending over a table with several forms of type. They are looking, at this moment, at a made-up headline - but Kane's back is in the way ... so we can't read it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly glances at his wrist watch and makes a face.  Kane smiles as he notices this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away, and we can now read the headline. Insert of the headline, which reads: "OIL THEFT BECOMES LAW AS PRESIDENT WITHOLDS VETO" DISSOLVE: Here follows a quick montage (presently to be worked out) of no more than four or five images in which the President, by means of cartoons, editorials, headlines (all faithfully reproduced from period yellow journalism) is violently attacked. The montage ends on the word TREASON.  The music cuts. A hand reaches in a side pocket which contains a newspaper - recognizably the "Enquirer."  The hand removes a gun.  The gun is shot.  Many arms seize the hand which is pulled up - gun still firing.  As the arm is raised in the air, we see that the other arms holding the arm and struggling with it are uniformed, and we see the White House beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : News ticker which is spelling out the words: "ASSASSINATED 7:45 P.M."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How about it, Mr. Kane?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: "OIL THEFT BECOMES LAW AS PRESIDENT WITHOLDS VETO" DISSOLVE

dialogue.raw_text: All right.  Let her slide!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: :  Under the following - a down shot, below the "Enquirer," shows a crowd forming, looking angrily up toward the camera. Crowd noises on the soundtrack under music. A hand snatches the ticker tape away and as the image of the crowd dissolves out, we pull back to show:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The ticker tape is in Reilly's hand.  Reilly has a phone to his ear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks bad for us, Mr. Kane.  How shall we handle it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGIE'S PLACE - Kane in shirtsleeves at phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Headline under "Enquirer" masthead which reads: "PRESIDENT ASSASSINATED" Newsboy is crying the headline at the same time.  We pull back to show him and - DISSOLVE:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a news story!  Get it on the street!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The camera is in tight on a box which contains Emily and distinguished elderly ladies and gentlemen, obviously family and friends.  On the soundtrack, very limpid opera music. Another elderly gent, in white tie but still wearing an overcoat, comes into the box and whispers to Emily.  He has a copy of the "Enquirer" in his hand.  Emily rises.  He shows the paper to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - An angry crowd seen from the window of Kane's office.  They make a deep threatening sound which is audible during the following scene.  Across the heads of the crowd are two great squares of light from the windows above them.  One of these disappears as the blind is pulled.  As the dissolve completes itself, the second square of light commences to reduce in size, and then the entire street is cut off by a blind which Leland pulls down, covering the entire frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The staff standing around, worried to death, in their shirtsleeves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane stops - looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland looks back at Kane, is conscious of the boys standing around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland walks out in to the City Room.  More staff members in shirt sleeves in a state of panic.  Leland goes to his desk, takes out a bottle, pours himself a very stiff drink.  A door opens.  A Policeman enters with Bernstein.  Bernstein is badly battered.  The boys crowd around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bernstein leaves the picture with sympathetic attendance. Leland finishes his second drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Reilly) Take dictation -  Front page editorial -  "This afternoon a great man was assassinated.  He was the President of the United States -" LELAND Charlie -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think you're the one who should call him a great man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?  Well - nobody's a great man in your estimation until he's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Maybe we'd better wait for more word on the President's condition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still looking at Leland) What do you mean by that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Competition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He may recover -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still holding on Leland) What do you mean by that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (steadily) Yesterday morning you called the President a traitor.  What do you think that crowd is doing down there?  They think you murdered him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because the crackpot who did it had a copy of the "Enquirer" in his pocket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - and that copy of the "Enquirer" said the President should be killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said treason was a capital offense punishable by death -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've said a lot of things about the President in the last few months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're true!  Everything I said! Witholding that veto was treason!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Charlie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (riding over him) Oil belonging to the people of the United States was leased out for a song to a gang of high-pressure crooks -  Nobody can blame me because -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look out that window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are the people of the United States, and they are blaming you - Oh, I know it doesn't make any sense, but at least you can learn a lesson from it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snarling) What lesson?  Not to expose fraud when I see it?  Not to fight for the right of the people to own their own property? (he turns to Reilly) Run it the way I said, Reilly - "This afternoon a great man was assassinated -" LELAND Charlie!  Now you're not making sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) I don't have to.  I run a newspaper with half a million readers and they're getting a martyred president this morning with their breakfast. I can't help that.  Besides, they all know I'm married to his niece. I've got to think of her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got to think of Emily -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a silence) I'd like to talk to you about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish your editorial.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worried) What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I'm all right, Mr. Leland.  Only there was some fellows out front that thought they ought to take things up with me.  I learned 'em! Didn't I, officer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) You sure did -  Say, the Commissioner said I was to stand by and protect Mr. Kane until further orders, no matter how he felt about it.  Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing his drink) In there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you hadn't come along and protected me when you did, I'd have killed them fellows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pouring himself another drink) Go and get yourself washed up, Mr. Bernstein. (he looks his face over thoroughly) There doesn't seem to be an serious injury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not to me.  But you will let that cop go home with Mr. Kane, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Bernstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The bottle is finished.  The door in the Sanctrum opens.  Reilly and the others leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane stands in the door, waiting for Leland.  Leland gets up and moves toward the office - goes in, sits down across from Kane at the desk.  An uncomfortable pause.  Then Kane smiles ingratiatingly.  Leland tries to cope with this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises and goes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane turns back to Leland.  Leland doesn't look up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane goes around behind the desk and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at Leland sharply before he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane takes this in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer from Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still no answer from Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at Leland, but Leland can't be stopped now.  He speaks very quietly - no poison in his voice - no personal indignation - as though he were explaining the nature of a disease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland has risen.  He speaks as he turns away, starting towards the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland has turned, taking his eye again.  Now Kane stops and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland shakes his head.  Kane lifts his glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as they go) Goodnight, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First of all - (he can't go on)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not cruelly - genuinely kind) What's wrong, Brad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get you some coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First of all, I will not write a good review of a play because somebody paid a thousand dollars for an advertisement in the "Enquirer."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently - opening the door) That's just a little promotion scheme.  Nobody expects you - (calling) Mike, will you try and get Mr. Leland some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure thing, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie, it's just no go.  We can't agree anymore.  I wish you'd let me go to Chicago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, Brad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to be transferred to the new paper.  You've been saying yourself you wish you had somebody to - (he is heartsick, inarticulate) That's not what I wanted to talk about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you what I'll do, Brad - I'll get drunk, too - maybe that'll help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that won't help.  Besides, you never get drunk.  I wanted to talk about you and Emily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without looking at him) She's going to leave you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so, Brad.  We've just had word that the President is out of danger. (ruefully) It seems I didn't kill him after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes his eye) She was going to leave you anyway -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emily's going south next week with the child.  As far as anybody's to know, it's a holiday.  When they get back -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) Brad, you are drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I am.  She wants full custody of the child no matter what happens. If you won't agree to that, she'll apply for a divorce regardless of the President's wishes.  I can't tell her she's wrong, because she isn't wrong -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is she leaving me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it's very hard for him to say all this) She hasn't any friends left sine you started this oil business, and she never sees you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think the "Enquirer" shouldn't have campaigned against the oil leases?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitating) You might have made the whole thing less personal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't just that the President was her uncle - everyone she knows, all the people she's been brought up with, everything she's ever been taught to believe is important -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no reason why this - this savage personal note -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The personal note is all there is to it.  It's all there ever is to it.  It's all there every is to anything!  Stupidity in our government, complacency and self- satisfaction and unwillingness to believe that anything done by a certain class of people can be wrong - you can't fight those things impersonally.  They're not impersonal crimes against people. They're being done by actual persons - with actual names and positions and - the right of the American people to own their own country is not an academic issue, Brad, that you debate - and then the judges retire to return a verdict and the winners give a dinner for the losers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You almost convince me. (rising) I'm just drunk enough to tell you the truth.  I have to be a little drunk for that because I'm a coward. You know that.  That's why you keep me around. (smiles) You only associate with your inferiors, Charlie.  I guess that's why you ran away from Emily. Because you can't stand the company of your equals.  You don't like to admit they exist - the other big people in your world are dead. I told you that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You talk about the people of the United States as though they belonged to you.  When you find out they don't think they are, you'll lose interest.  You talk about giving them their rights as though you could make a present of liberty.  Remember the working man?  You used to defend him quite a good deal.  Well, he's turning into something called organized labor and you don't like that at all.  And listen, when your precious underprivileged really get together - that's going to add up to something bigger than - than your privilege and then I don't know what you'll do - sail away to a desert island, probably, and lord it over the monkeys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you finished?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. (looking down) Now, will you let me go to Chicago?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a little smile) You're not going to like it in Chicago.  They wind comes howling in from the lake.  And there's practically no opera season at all - and the Lord only knows whether they've ever heard of Lobster Newburg -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right. (he won't be charmed out of his duty) What are you going to do about Emily?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his face hardning a little) Nothing - if she dosen't love me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want love on your own terms, don't you, Charlie - (he stops - his back turned to Kane) Love according to your own rules. And if anything goes wrong and you're hurt - then the game stops, and you've got to be soothed and nursed, no matter what else is happening - and no matter who else is hurt!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's simpler than that, Brad.  A society girl can't stand the gaff, that's all.  Other things are important to her - social position, what they're saying on the front porches at Southampton, is it going to be embarrassing to meet somebody or the other at dinner -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She can leave me.  As a matter of fact, I've already left her.  Don't worry, Brad - I'll live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with all his charm) Hey, Brad!  I've been analyzed an awful lot tonight - let's have another brandy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To love on my terms.  Those are the only terms anybody knows ... his own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Kane, Leland, and a couple of policemen make their way out of the front toward a hansom cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A rock is thrown.  It hits Leland on the face.  A little blood flows.  Kane doesn't see it at first.  Then when he's in the hansom cab, he turns and notices it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland has a handkerchief to his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd, pushed by the cops, retreats in the background, but still hard by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hansom cab starts up.  We hold on Leland's face as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You moiderer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  I wish you'd go home to Emily. She'll be pretty upset by all this - She still loves you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You still want to be transferred to the other paper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning out of the hansom cab) Well, you've been getting a pretty low salary here in New York.  It seems to me that the new dramatic critic of our Chicago paper should get what he's worth. (almost as a question)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with handkerchief still attached to his face) I couldn't possibly live on as little as that, Charlie.  We'll let the salary stay where it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KANE'S NEW YORK HOME - KANE'S BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING - Emily is in bed, a damp cloth over her temples.  Kane is standing at the foot of the bed.  The baby's bed is in a corner of the room.  The baby's nurse is standing near the crib, a nurse for Emily is near her.  Kane is looking fixedly on Emily, who is staring tiredly at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse looks at Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse, unwilling, leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops.  He sees that he's getting no place with Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits for her to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits up and looks at the crib.  She almost continues to look at the crib, with almost unseeing eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane is about to say something, but bites his lips instead. Emily keeps staring at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily nods several times.  There is an uncomforable silence. Suddenly there is a cry from the crib.  Emily leaps from the bed and rushes to him.  She bends over the crib.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane, unwanted, ignored, looks on.  Tightening his lips, he walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the nurse) Excuse us a moment, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (peremptorily) I said, excuse us a moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been talking to Leland.  Emily - You can't leave me now - not now -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't what it would do to my changes in politics, Emily -  That isn't it -  They were talking of running me for governor, but now, of course, we'll have to wait - It isn't that, Emily -  It's just - the president is your uncle and they're saying I killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That story about the murderer having a copy of the "Enquirer" in his pocket - the "Chronicle" made that up out of whole cloth -  Emily, please - He's going to be all right, you know, he's going to recover - (bitterly) If it will make you any happier, we had nine pages of advertising cancelled in the first mail this morning.  Bernstein is afraid to open any more letters.  He -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) What do you expect me to do?  What in the world -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you really think - (she can't continue) Those threatening letters, can they really -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortably) They won't do anything to Junior, darling. (contemptuously) Anonymous letter writers -   I've got guards in front of the house, and I'm going to arrange -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning her face toward him) Please don't talk any more, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have they heard from father yet? Has he seen -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've tried to tell you, Emily. The President's going to be all right.  He had a comfortable night. There's no danger of any kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (murmuring) Here I am, darling...  Darling!... Darling, it's all right...  Mother's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emily - you musn't leave me now - you can't do that to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They won't hurt you, darling. Mother's with you!  Mother's looking after you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: By the desk light, Kane is seen working with his usual intensity,  Reilly standing beside him at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane is perplexed and worried, but we can see in a moment his mind will be on something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane doesn't answer.  Reilly goes on.  He has brought out a piece of paper and is reading it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane has looked up sharply.  Reilly, sensing his look, stops reading and meets his eye.  Slowly, Kane reaches out his hand. Reilly hands him the piece of paper.  Without reading it, Kane tears it up, throws it into the wastebasket at his side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll withdraw support completely. Anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Leland sent back that check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What check?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You made it out to him last week after he left for Chicago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, the bonus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was for twenty-five thousand dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sent it back torn up - all torn up into little bits, and he enclosed something else -  I can't make it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It says here, "A Declaration of Principles" - (he still reads)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: will provide the people of this city with a daily paper that will tell all the news honestly" -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The evening of the final great rally.  These shots remind us of and are identical with and supplementary to the "News Digest" scenes earlier.  The vast auditorium with a huge picture of Kane, cheering crowds, etc.  Emily and Junior are to be seen in the front of a box.  Emily is tired and wears a forced smile on her face.  Junior, now aged nine and a half, is eager, bright- eyed and excited.  Kane is just finishing his speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrific screaming and cheering from the audience.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is no secret that I entered upon this campaign with no thought that I could be elected Governor of this state!  It is now no secret that every straw vote, every independent pole, shows that I will be elected.  And I repeat to you - my first official act as Governor will be to appoint a special District Attorney to arrange for the indictment, prosecution and conviction of Boss Edward G. Rogers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The Speaker's Platform.  Numerous officials and civic leaders are crowding around Kane.  Cameramen take flash photographs with old-fashioined flash powder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up and notices that the box in which Emily and the boy were sitting is now empty.  He starts toward the rear of the platform, through the press of people, Reilly approaches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane pats him on the shoulder as he walks along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is said almost inquiringly, as if he were hoping that Kane would give him some assurance that McDonald is not making a mistake.  There is no answer from Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane is very pleased.  He continues with Reilly slowly through the crowd - a band playing off.  Bernstein joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane indicates he is to proceed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Great speech, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pompous) One of the most notable public utterances ever made by a candidate in this state -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, gentlemen.  Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A wonderful speech, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just got word from Buffalo, Mr. Kane.  They're going to throw you the organization vote - and take a chance maybe you'll give them a break -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On an independent ticket there's never been anything like it!  If the election were held today, you'd be elected by a hundred thousand votes - and every day between now and November 7th is just going to add to your majority.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It does seem too good to be true, doesn't it, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rogers isn't even pretending.  He isn't just scared anymore.  He's sick.  Frank Norris told me last night he hasn't known Rogers to be that worried in twenty-five years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's beginning to dawn on Mr. Rogers that I mean what I say. With Mr. Rogers out of the way, Reilly, I think we may really begin to hope for a good government in this state. (stopping) Well, Mr. Bernstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clearly not meaning it) It's wonderful, Mr. Kane. Wonderful.  Wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't really think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do.  I do.  I mean, since you're running for Governor - and you want to be elected -  I think it's wonderful you're going to be elected.  Only - (interrupts himself) -  Can I say something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Mr. Bernstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the way I look at it - (comes out with it) -  You want to know what I really think would be wonderful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're running for Governor and going to be elected - my idea is how wonderful it would be if you don't run at all and don't get elected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Emily and Junior are standing, waiting for Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, Kane appears, with Reilly and several other men. Kane rushes toward Emily and Junior, as the men politely greet Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are good nights.  Kane's car is at the curb and he starts to walk toward it with Junior and Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver is holding the rear door open as Emily guides Junior in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cab has pulled up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily nods to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane's reaction indicates that the address definitely means something to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the door and she enters the cab.  He follows her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is Pop Governor yet, Mom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Butch!  Did you like your old man's speech?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Pop!  I was in a box.  I could hear every word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw you! (he has his arm around Junior's shoulder) Good night, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sending Junior home in the car, Charles - with Oliver -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'd arranged to go home with you myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a call I want you to make with me, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it can't. (she bends down and kisses Junior) Good night, darling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as car starts to drive off) What's this all about, Emily? I've had a very tiring day and -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It may not be about anything at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cab?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I intend to find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I insist on being told exactly what you have in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to - (she looks at a slip of paper in her hand)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: West 74th Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you wish, you can come with me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Kane and Emily.  He looks at her, in search of some kind of enlightenment.  Her face is set and impassive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . APARTMENT HOUSE HALLWAY - NIGHT - Kane and Emily, in front of an apartment door.  Emily is pressing the bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily does not answer.  The door is opened by a maid, who recognizes Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They enter, Emily first.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I had no idea you had this flair for melodrama, Emiliy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in, Mr. Kane, come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - There is first a tiny reception room, through which an open door shows the living room.  Kane and Emily enter from the hallway and cross to the living room.  As they enter, Susan rises from a chair.  The other person  in the room - a big, heavyset man, a little past middle age - stays where he is, leaning back in his chair, regarding Kane intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane starts to stare at him intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily looks at Kane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him.  He starts to work himself into a rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks out.  Rogers stops as he gets directly in front of Kane.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't my fault, Charlie.  He made me send your wife a note. He said I'd - oh, he's been saying the most terrible things, I didn't know what to do...  I - (she catches sight of Emily)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Mr. Kane. (he rises) I don't suppose anybody would introduce us.  Mrs. Kane, I am Edward Rogers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do? (pauses) I came here - and I made Mr. Kane come with me... (she consults the note in her hand without reading it again) because I recieved this note -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I made Miss - Miss Alexander send you the note.  She was a little unwilling at first - (he smiles grimly) but she did it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't tell you the things he said, Charlie.  You haven't got any idea -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning on Rogers) Rogers, I don't think I will postpone doing something about you until I'm elected. (he starts toward him) To start with, I'll break your neck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not giving way an inch) Maybe you can do it and maybe you can't, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles! (he stops to look at her) Your - your breaking this man's neck - (she is clearly disgusted) would scarcely explain this note - (glancing at the note) Serious consequences for Mr. Kane - (slowly) for myself, and for my son.  What does this note mean, Miss -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffly) I'm Susan Alexander. (pauses) I know what you think, Mrs. Kane, but -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring this) What does this note mean, Miss Alexander?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She doesn't know, Mrs. Kane.  She just sent it - because I made her see it wouldn't be smart for her not to send it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In case you don't know, Emily, this - this gentleman - (he puts a world of scorn into the word) is -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not a gentleman, Mrs. Kane, and your husband is just trying to be funny calling me one.  I don't even know what a gentleman is. (tensely, with all the hatred and venom in the world) You see, my idea of a gentleman, Mrs.  Kane - well, if I owned a newspaper and if I didn't like the way somebody else was doing things - some politican, say - I'd fight them with everything I had.  Only I wouldn't show him in a convict suit, with stripes - so his children could see the picture in the paper. Or his mother. (he has to control himself from hurling himself at Kane) It's pretty clear - I'm not a gentleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a cheap, crooked grafter - and your concern for your children and your mother -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything you say, Mr. Kane.  Only we're talking now about what you are.  That's what the note is about, Mrs. Kane.  Now I'm going to lay all my cards on the table.  I'm fighting for my life.  Not just my political life.  My life.  If your husband is elected governor -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to be elected governor. And the first thing I'm going to do -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let him finish, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm protecting myself every way I know how, Mrs. Kane.  This last week, I finally found out how I can stop your husband from being elected.  If the people of this state learn what I found out this week, he wouldn't have a chance to - he couldn't be elected Dog Catcher. Well, what I'm interested in is seeing that he's not elected.  I don't care whether they know what I know about him.  Let him keep right on being the Great, Noble, Moral - (he stresses the world) Champeen of the people.  Just as long as -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I understand, Mr. Rogers, but wonder if - (she leaves her sentence unfinished)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't blackmail me, Rogers, you can't -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) Charlie, he said, unless you withdrew your name -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the chance I'm willing to give you, Mr. Kane.  More of a chance than you'd give me.  Unless you make up your mind by tomorrow that you're so sick that you've got to go away for a year or two - Monday morning every paper in this State will carry the story I'm going to give them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What story, Mr. Rogers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The story about him and Miss Alexander, Mrs. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no story.  It's all lies. Mr. Kane is just -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Susan) Shut up! (to Kane) I've had a dozen men doing nothing but run this thing down - we've got evidence enough to - well, the evidence would stand up in any court of law.  You want me to give you the evidence, Mr. Kane?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do anything you want to do. The people of this state can decide which one of us to trust.  If you want to know, they've already decided.  The election Tuesday'll be only -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Kane, I'm not asking you to believe me.  I'd like to show you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to show me anything, Mr. Rogers.  I believe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather Mr. Kane withdrew without having to get the story published. Not that I care about him.  But I'd be better off that way - (he pauses) - and so would you, Mrs. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about me? (to Kane) He said my name'd be dragged through the mud.  He said everywhere I'd go from now on -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There seems to be only one decision you can make, Charles.  I'd say that it has been made for you. (pauses) I suppose the details can be arranged tomorrow, Mr. Rogers. About the statements by the doctors -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you gone completely mad, Emily?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think I'm going to let this blackmailer intimidate me, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see what else you can do, Charles.  If he's right - and the papers publish this story he has -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they'll publish it all right. But that's not going to stop me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles, this - this story - doesn't concern only you.  I'll be in it, too, won't I? (quickly) And Junior?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squirming a bit) I suppose so, but - I'm not afraid of the story.  You can't tell me that the voters of this state -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not interested in the voters of this state right now.  I am interested in - well, Junior, for one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie!  If they publish this story -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They won't.  Goodnight, Mr. Rogers. (she starts out) There's nothing more to be said, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so.  Are you coming, Charles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's only one person in the world to decide what I'm going to do - and that's me.  And if you think - if any of you think -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You decided what you were going to do, Charles - some time ago. (she looks at Susan) You can't always have it your own way, regardless of anything else that may have happened. (she sighs) Come on, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on!  Get out!  I can fight this thing all alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're making a bigger fool of yourself than I thought you would, Mr. Kane.  You're licked.  Why don't you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning on him) Get out!  I've got nothing to talk to you about.  If you want to see me, have the Warden write me a letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see! (he starts toward the door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting to cry) Charlie, you're just excited.  You don't realize -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know exactly what I'm doing. (he is screaming) Get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Charles, if you don't listen to reason, it may be too late -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too late for what?  Too late for you and this - (he can't find the adjective) this public thief to take the love of the people of this state away from me?  Well, you won't do it, I tell you.  You won't do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie, there are other things to think of. (a sly look comes into her eyes) Your son - you don't want him to read in the papers -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is too late now, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rushes to the door and opens it) Get out, both of you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rushes to him) Charlie, please don't -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you waiting here for? Why don't you go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the greatest fool I've ever known, Kane.  If it was anybody else, I'd say what's going to happen to you would be a lesson to you. Only you're going to need more than one lesson.  And you're going to get more than one lesson. (he walks past Kane)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you worry about me.  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  I'm no cheap, crooked politician, trying to save himself from the consequences of his crimes -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane is trembling with rage as he shakes his fist at Rogers's back.  Susan, quieter now, has snuggled into the hollow of his shoulder as they stand in the doorway.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Brad -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emily -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry I sent for you, Brad - didn't -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are all the returns in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me see it.

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Almost two to one -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm surprised he got the votes he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emily!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should anyone vote for him? He's made it quite clear to the people what he thinks of them. Children - to be told one thing one day, something else the next, as the whim seizes him.  And they're supposed to be grateful and love and adore him - because he sees to it that they get cheap ice and only pay a nickel in the street cars.

dialogue.raw_text: Emily, you're being - a little unfair -  You know what I think of Charles' behavior - about your personal lives -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There aren't any personal lives for people like us.  He made that very clear to me nine years ago - If I'd thought of my life with Charles as a personal life, I'd have left him then -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: know that, Emily -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on top of Leland) Maybe I should have - the first time he showed me what a mad dog he really was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the cue "dog") Emily, you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brad, I'm -  I'm not an old woman yet -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's - all over -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Know it is, Brad -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's paying for it, Emily.  Those returns tonight - he's finished. Politically - (he thinks) - socially, everywhere, I guess. don't know about the papers, but -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're asking me to sympathize with him, Brad, you're wasting your time. (pauses) There's only one person I'm sorry for, as a matter of fact.  That - that shabby little girl.  I'm really sorry for her, Brad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SET FOR "THAIS" - The camera is just inside the curtain, angling upstage.  We see the set for "Thais" - the principals in place - stage managers, stage hands, etc., and in the center of all this, in an elaborate costume, looking very small and very lost, is Susan.  She is almost hysterical with fright.  Maids, singing teacher, and the rest are in attendance.  Her throat is sprayed. Applause is heard at the opening of the shot, and now the orchestra starts thunderously.  The curtain starts to rise - the camera with it - the blinding glare of the foots moves up Susan's body and hits her face.  She squints and starts to sing.  Camera continues on up with the curtain, up past Susan, up the full height of the proscenium arch and then on up into the gridiron into a world of ropes, brick walls and hanging canvas - Susan's voice still heard - but faintly.  The camera stops at the top of the gridiron as the curtain stops.  Two typical stage hands fill the frame.  They are looking down on the stage below.  Some of the reflected light gleams on their faces.  They look at each other.  One of them puts his hand to his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Leland, as in the same scene in the Bernstein sequence, is sprawled across his typewriter, his head on the keys.  The paper is gone from the roller.  Leland stirs and looks up drunkenly, his eyes encountering Bernstein, who stands beside him (also as in the previous scene).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland makes a terrific effort to pull himself together.  He straightens and reaches for the keys - then sees the paper is gone from the machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During all this, the sound of a typewriter has been heard off - a busy typewriter.  Leland's eyes follow the sound.  Slowly he registers Kane in the City Room beyond.  This is almost the same shot as in the previous Bernstein story.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kane?  Charlie? (painfully, he rises to his feet) Where is he?

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Kane, in white tie and shirt sleeves, is typing away at a machine, his fingers working briskly and efficiently, his face, seen by the desk light before him, set in a strange half-smile. Leland stands in the door of his office, staring across at him.

direction.raw_text: Leland turns incredulously to Bernstein.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leland picks his way across the City Room to Kane's side. Kane goes on typing, without looking up.  After a pause, Kane speaks.

direction.raw_text: Kane stops typing, but doesn't turn.

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose he's fixing it up - I know I'd never get that through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving to his side) Mr. Kane is finishing your piece the way you started it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's writing a roast like you wanted it to be - (then suddnely - with a kind of quiet passion rather than a triumph) - I guess that'll show you.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Brad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Thompson and Leland on the roof, which is now deserted.  It is getting late.  The sun has just about gone down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Nurse appears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's about all there is - and I'm getting chills.  Hey, nurse! (pause) Five years ago, he wrote from that place of his down South - (as if trying to think) - you know.  Shangri-la?  El Dorado? (pauses) Sloppy Joe's?  What's the name of that place?  You know...  All right. Xanadu.  I knew what it was all the time.  You caught on, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess maybe I'm not as hard to see through as I think.  Anyway, I never even answered his letter. Maybe I should have.  I guess he was pretty lonely down there those last years.  He hadn't finished it when she left him - he never finished it - he never finished anything.  Of course, he built it for her -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That must have been love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  He was disappointed in the world.  So he built one of his own -  An absolute monarchy - It was something bigger than an opera house anyway - (calls) Nurse! (lowers his voice) Say, I'll tell you one thing you can do for me, young fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On your way out, stop at a cigar store, will you, and send me up a couple of cigars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, Mr. Leland.  I'll be glad to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Nurse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm ready to go in now.  You know when I was a young man, there was an impression around that nurses were pretty.  It was no truer then than it is now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, let me take your arm, Mr. Leland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (testily) All right, all right. (he has begun to move forward on the Nurse's arm; turning to Thompson) You won't forget, will you, about the cigars?  And tell them to wrap them up to look like toothpaste, or something, or they'll stop them at the desk.  That young doctor I was telling you about, he's got an idea he wants to keep me alive.

result.heading: "EL RANCHO" FLOOR SHOW SUSAN ALEXANDER KANE TWICE NIGHTLY

direction.raw_text: EARLY DAWN - Susan and Thompson are facing each other.  The place is almost deserted.  Susan is sober.  On the other side of the room, somebody is playing a piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan is thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson looks at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How do you want to handle the whole thing - ask questions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather you just talked. Anything that comes into your mind - about yourself and Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't want to hear a lot of what comes into my mind about myself and Mr. Charlie Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you meet him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a toothache.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was thiry years ago - and I still remember that toothache. Boy!  That toothache was just driving me crazy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Susan, aged twenty, neatly but cheaply dressed in the style of the period, is leaving the drug store.  It's about 8 o'clock at night.  With a large, man-sized handkerchief pressed to her cheek, she is in considerable pain.  The street is wet - after a recent rain. She walks a few steps towards the middle of the block, and can stand it no longer.  She stops, opens a bottle of Oil of Cloves that she has in her hand, applies some to her finger, and rubs her gums. She walks on, the pain only a bit better.  Four or five houses farther along, she comes to what is clearly her own doorway - a shabby, old four-story apartment house.  She turns toward the doorway, which is up a tiny stoop, about three steps. As she does so, Kane, coming from the opposite direction, almost bumps into her and turns to his left to avoid her.  His shoulder bumps hers and she turns.  As she does so, Kane, forced to change his course, steps on the loose end of a plank which covers a puddle in the bad sidewalk.  The plank rises up and cracks him on the knee, also covering him with mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan, taking her handkerchief from her jaw, roars with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bites his lip and rubs his knee again.  Susan tries to control her laughter, but not very successfully.  Kane glares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, the pain returns and she claps her hand to her jaw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has been rubbing his clothes with his handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan starts to laugh again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the middle of her smile, the pain returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan starts, with Kane following her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - It's in moderate disorder.  The Mansbach gas lights are on. It's not really a classy room, but it's exactly what you're entitled to in 1910, for $5.00 a week including breakfast. There is a bed, a couple of chairs, a chiffonier, and a few personal belongings on the chiffonier.  These include a photograph of a gent and lady, obviously Susan's parents, and a few objets d'art.  One, "At the Japanese Rolling Ball Game at Coney Island," and - perhaps this is part of the Japanese loot - the glass globe with the snow scene Kane was holding in his hand in the first sequence. Susan comes into the room, carrying a basin, with towels over her arm.  Kane is waiting for her.  She doesn't close the door.
