dialogue.raw_text: (looks squarely at her) You really don't know who I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  That is, I bet it turns out I've heard your name a million times, only you know how it is -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you like me, don't you?  Even though you don't know who I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been wonderful!  I can't tell you how glad I am you're here, I don't know many people and - (she stops)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I know too many people. Obviously, we're both lonely. (he smiles) Would you like to know where I was going tonight - when you ran into me and ruined my Sunday clothes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't run into you and I bet they're not your Sunday clothes. You've probably got a lot of clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if defending himself from a terrible onslaught) I was only joking! (pauses) This evening I was on my way to the Western Manhattan Warehouses - in search of my youth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, my mother died, too - a long time ago.  Her things were put into storage out west because I had no place to put them then. I still haven't.  But now I've sent for them just the same.  And tonight I'd planned to make a sort of sentimental journey - (slowly) - to the scenes of my youth - my childhood, I suppose - to look again at - (he changes mood slightly) and now -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who am I?  Well, let's see.  Charles Foster Kane was born in New Salem, Colorado in eighteen six - (he stops on the word "sixty" - obviously a little embarrassed) I run a couple of newspapers.  How about you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How old did you say you were?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very bright) I didn't say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't think you did.  If you had, I wouldn't have asked you again, because I'd have remembered. How old?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty old.  I'll be twenty-two in August.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at her silently for a moment) That's a ripe old age -  What do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I work at Seligman's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what you want to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to be a singer. (she thinks for a moment) I mean, I didn't.  Mother did for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sympathetically) What happened to the singing? You're not in a show, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no!  Nothing like that.  Mother always thought - she used to talk about Grand Opera for me.  Imagine! An American girl, for one thing - and then my voice isn't really that kind anyway, it's just that Mother - you know what mothers are like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a matter of fact, I do sing a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points to the piano) Would you sing for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bashful) Oh, you wouldn't want to hear me sing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I would.  That's why I asked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me your toothache is bothering you again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, that's all gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you have no alibi at all. Please sing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: EARLY DAWN - Susan tosses down a drink, then goes on with her story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I did a lot of singing after that. I sang for Charlie -  I sang for teachers at a hundred bucks an hour - the teachers got that, I didn't -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you get?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glares at him balefully) What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't get a thing.  Just the music lessons.  That's all there was to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He married you, didn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was in love with me.  But he never told me so until after it all came out in the papers about us - and he lost the election and that Norton woman divorced him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about that apartment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wanted me to be comfortable - Oh, why should I bother?  You don't believe me, but it's true.  It just happens to be true.  He was really interested in my voice. (sharply) What are you smiling for?  What do you think he built that opera house for?  I didn't want it.  I didn't want to sing.  It was his idea - everything was his idea - except my leaving him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Susan is singing.  Matisti, her voice teacher, is playing the piano.  Kane is seated nearby.  Matisti stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a silence.  Matisti rises.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: LIVING ROOM OF KANE'S HOUSE IN NEW YORK

dialogue.raw_text: Impossible!  Impossible!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your job isn't to give Mrs. Kane your opinion of her talents. You're supposed to train her voice. Nothing more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sweating) But, it is impossible.  I will be the laughingstock of the musical world!  People will say -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're interested in what people say, Signor Matisti, I may be able to enlighten you a bit.  The newspapers, for instance.  I'm an authority on what the papers will say, Signor Matisti, because I own eight of them between here and San Francisco...  It's all right, dear. Signor Matisti is going to listen to reason.  Aren't you, maestro? (he looks him square in the eyes)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Kane, how can I persuade you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd see it my way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - It is the same opening night - it is the same moment as before - except taht the camera is now upstage angling toward the audience.  The curtain is down.  We see the same tableau as before - the terrified and trembling Susan, the apprehensive principals, the maids and singing teachers, the stage hands. As the dissolve commences, there is the sound of applause (exactly as before) and now as the dissolve completes itself, the orchestra breaks frighteningly into opening chords of the music - the stage is cleared - Susan is left alone, terribly alone.  The curtain rises.  The glare of the footlights jump into the image.  The curtain is now out of the picture and Susan starts to sing.  Beyond her, we see the prompter's box, containing the anxious face of the prompter.  Beyond that, out in the darkness - an apprehensive conductor struggles with his task of coordinating an orchestra and an incompetent singer. Beyond that - dimly white shirt fronts and glistening bosoms for a couple of rows, and then deep and terrible darkness. Closeup of Kane's face - seated in the audience - listening. Sudden but perfectly correct lull in the music reveals a voice from the audience - a few words from a sentence - the kind of thing that often happens in a theatre -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Music crashes in and drowns out the rest of the sentence, but hundreds of people around the voice have heard it (as well as Kane) and there are titters which grow in volume. Closeup of Susan's face - singing. Closeup of Kane's face - listening. There is the ghastly sound of three thousand people applauding as little as possible.  Kane still looks.  Then, near the camera, there is the sound of about a dozen people applauding very, very loudly.  Camera moves back, revealing Bernstein and Reilly and other Kane stooges, seated around him, beating their palms together.  The curtain is falling - as we can see by the light which shutters down off their faces. The stage from Kane's angle. The curtain is down - the lights glowing on it.  Still, the polite applause dying fast.  Nobody comes out for a bow. Closeup of Kane - breathing heavily.  Suddenly he starts to applaud furiously. The stage from the audience again. Susan appears for her bow.  She can hardly walk.  There is a little polite crescendo of applause, but it is sickly. Closeup of Kane - still applauding very, very hard, his eyes on Susan. The stage again. Susan, finishing her bow, goes out through the curtains.  The light on the curtain goes out and the houselights go on. Closeup of Kane - still applauding very, very hard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: - really pathetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: KANE'S NEW YORK HOME - DAY - Some weeks later.  Susan, in a negligee, is at the window. There are the remains of her breakfast tray on a little table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane rises and walks toward her.  There is cold menace in his walk.  Susan shrinks a little as he draws closer to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are relentlessly upon her.  She sees something in them that frightens her.  She nods her head slowly, indicating surrender.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't propose to have yourself made ridiculous?  What about me? I'm the one that has to do the singing.  I'm the one that gets the razzberries. (pauses) Last week, when I was shopping, one of the salesgirls did an imitation of me for another girl. She thought I didn't see her, but - Charlie, you might as well make up your mind to it.  This is one thing you're not going to have your own way about.  I can't sing and you know it -  Why can't you just -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My reasons satisfy me, Susan.  You seem unable to understand them.  I will not tell them to you again. (he is very close to her) You will continue with your singing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Front page of the "San Francisco Enquirer" containing a large portrait of Susan as Thais (as before).  It is announced that Susan will open an independent season in San Francisco in "Thais."  The picture remains constant but the names of the papers change from New York to St. Louis, to Los Angeles to Cleveland, to Denver to Philadelphia - all "Enquirers." During all this, on the soundtrack, Susan's voice is heard singing her aria very faintly and far away, her voice cracking a little. At the conclusion of this above, Susan has finished her song, and there is the same mild applause as before - over the sound of this, one man loudly applauding.  This fades out as we -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KANE'S NEW YORK HOME - LATE NIGHT - The camera angles across the bed and Susan's form towards the door, from the other side of which voices can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door crashes open, light floods in the room, revealing Susan, fully dressed, stretched out on the bed, one arm dangling over the side.  Kane rushes to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rushes out.  Susan is breathing, but heavily.  Kane loosens the lace collar at her throat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's have your keys, Raymond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The key must be in the other side. (pause) We'll knock the door down, Raymond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Mrs. Kane -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do what I say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get Dr. Corey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE NIGHT - A little later.  All the lights are lit.  Susan, in a nightgown, is in bed, asleep.  Raymond and a nurse are just leaving the room, Raymond closing the door quietly behind him.  Dr. Corey rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane nods.  He has a small bottle in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Corey leaves.  Kane settles himself in a chair next to the bed, looking at Susan.  In a moment, the nurse enters, goes to a chair in the corner of the room, and sits down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . COREY She'll be perfectly all right in a day or two, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . COREY The nurse has complete instructions, but if you care to talk to me at any time, I should be only too glad -  I shall be here in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.  I can't imagine how Mrs. Kane came to make such a silly mistake.  The sedative Dr. Wagner gave her is in a somewhat larger bottle -  I suppose the strain of preparing for her trip has excited and confused her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . COREY I'm sure that's it. (he starts out)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are no objections to my staying here with her, are there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . COREY Not at all.  I'd like the nurse to be here, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Susan, utterly spent, is lying flat on her back in her bed. Kane is in the chair beside her.  The nurse is out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan's head turns and she looks at him silently with pathetic eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gratefully, Susan, with difficulty, brings her other hand over to cover his.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in a voice that comes from far away) I couldn't make you see how I felt, Charlie.  I just couldn't -  I couldn't go threw with singing again.  You don't know what it means to feel - to know that people - that an audience don't want you. That if you haven't got what they want - a real voice - they just don't care about you. Even when they're polite - and they don't laugh or get restless or - you know...  They don't want you.  They just -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) That's when you've got to fight them.  That's when you've got to make them.  That's -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. (he leans over to pat her hand) You won't have to fight them anymore. (he smiles a little) It's their loss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ESTABLISHING SHOT OF XANADU - HALF BUILT INT. THE GRAND HALL IN XANADU - Closeup of an enormous jigsaw puzzle.  A hand is putting in the last piece.  Camera moves back to reveal jigsaw puzzle spread out on the floor. Susan is on the floor before her jigsaw puzzle.  Kane is in an easy chair.  Behind them towers the massive Renaissance fireplace.  It is night and Baroque candelabra illuminates the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane looks at her smilingly and turns back to his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is still no answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with a sigh) What time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie!  I said, what time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up - consults his watch) Half past eleven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean in New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half past eleven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.  The bulldog's just gone to press.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically) Hurray for the bulldog! (sighs) Half past eleven!  The shows have just let out.  People are going to night clubs and restaurants.  Of course, we're different.  We live in a palace - at the end of the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You always said you wanted to live in a palace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't we go back, Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I promise to be a good girl! Not to drink - and to entertain all the governors and the senators with dignity - (she puts a slur into the word) Charlie -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Another picture puzzle - Susan's hands fitting in a missing piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Another picture puzzle - Susan's hands fitting in a missing piece. DISSOLVE:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - Another picture puzzle. Camera pulls back to show Kane and Susan in much the same positions as before, except that they are older.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan shoots him an angry glance.  She isn't amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane has looked at her steadily, not hostilely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane turns away - to Bernstein.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the soundtrack we hear the following lines of dialogue:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this, camera holds on closeup of Susan's face.  She is very angry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: One thing I've never been able to understand, Susan.  How do you know you haven't done them before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It makes a whole lot more sense than collecting Venuses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may be right -  I sometimes wonder - but you get into the habit -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snapping) It's not a habit.  I do it because I like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was referring to myself. (pauses) I thought we might have a picnic tomorrow - it might be a nice change after the Wild West party tonight. Invite everybody to go to the Everglades -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (throws down a piece of the jigsaw puzzle and rises) Invite everybody!  Order everybody, you mean, and make them sleep in tents!  Who wants to sleep in tents when they have a nice room of their own - with their own bath, where they know where everything is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we might invite everybody to go on a picnic tomorrow.  Stay at Everglades overnight. (he pats her lightly on the shoulder) Please see that the arrangements are made, Susan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You remember my son, Mr. Bernstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrased) Oh, yes.  How do you do, Mr. Kane?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .'S VOICE Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Long shot - of a number of classy tents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Two real beds have been set up on each side of the tent.  A rather classy dressing table is in the rear, at which Susan is preparing for bed.  Kane, in his shirt-sleeves, is in an easy chair, reading.  Susan is very sullen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane turns to look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him, with no lessening of her passion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without a word, Kane slaps her across the face.  They look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane continues to look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other, fixedly, but she doesn't give way. In fact, the camera on Kane's face shows the beginning of a startled look, as of one who sees something unfamiliar and unbelievable.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to put up with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it. (she catches a slight flicker on Kane's face) Oh, I know I always say I mean it, and then I don't - or you get me so don't do what I say I'm going to - but -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) You're in a tent, darling.  You're not at home.  And I can hear you very well if you just talk in a normal tone of voice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to have my guests insulted, just because you think - (in a rage) - if people want to bring a drink or two along on a picnic, that's their business.  You've got no right -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) I've got more than a right as far as you're concerned, Susan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm sick and tired of you telling me what I must and what I musn't do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) You're my wife, Susan, and -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not just your wife, I'm a person all by myself - or I ought to be. I was once.  Sometimes you get me to believing I never was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can discuss all this some other time, Susan.  Right now -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll discuss what's on my mind when I want to.  You're not going to keep on running my life the way you want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As far as you're concerned, Susan, I've never wanted anything -  I don't want anything now - except what you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you want me to want, you mean. What you've decided I ought to have - what you'd want if you were me.  But you've never given me anything that -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susan, I really think -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I don't mean the things you've given me - that don't mean anything to you.  What's the difference between giving me a bracelet or giving somebody else a hundred thousand dollars for a statue you're going to keep crated up and never look at?  It's only money.  It doesn't mean anything.  You're not really giving anything that belongs to you, that you care about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he has risen) Susan, I want you to stop this. And right now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm not going to stop it. I'm going to say exactly what I think. (she screams) You've never given me anything. You've tried to buy me into giving you something.  You're - (a sudden notion) - it's like you were bribing me! That's what it's been from the first moment I met you.  No matter how much it cost you - your time, your money - that's what you've done with everybody you've ever known.  Tried to bribe them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susan!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're talking an incredible amount of nonsense, Susan. (quietly) Whatever I do -  I do - because I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love!  You don't love anybody!  Me or anybody else!  You want to be loved - that's all you want!  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  Whatever you want - just name it and it's yours! Only love me!  Don't expect me to love you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You - you hit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll never have another chance to hit me again. (pauses) Never knew till this minute -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susan, it seems to me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me you're sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to leave you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you're not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Kane is a the window looking out.  He turns as he hears Raymond enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond waits as Kane hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane impetuously walks past him out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Kane would like to see you, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Mrs. Kane - (he can't finish)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Marie has been packing since morning, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - Packed suitcases are on the floor, Susan is completely dressed for travelling.  Kane bursts into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaves.  Kane closes the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane is standing against the door as if physically barring her way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane keeps looking at her.  Susan reaches out her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has lost all pride.  Susan stops.  She is affected by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is staring at him.  She might weaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's as if he had thrown ice water into her face.  She freezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks out, past Kane, who turns to watch her go, like a very tired old man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Arnold I'm ready, Marie.  He can get the bags.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mrs. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you gone completely crazy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you realize that everybody here is going to know about this? That you've packed your bags and ordered the car and -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - And left?  Of course they'll hear.  I'm not saying goodbye - except to you - but I never imagined that people wouldn't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't let you go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't stop me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Charlie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly) Don't go, Susan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not start all over again, Charlie.  We've said everything that can be said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susan, don't go!  Susan, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mustn't go, Susan. Everything'll be exactly the way you want it.  Not the way I think you want it - by your way.  Please, Susan - Susan!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't go, Susan!  You mustn't go! (almost blubbering) You - you can't do this to me, Susan -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see - it's you that this is being done to!  It's not me at all.  Not how I feel.  Not what it means to me. (she laughs) I can't do this to you! (she looks at him) Oh, yes I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Susan and Thompson at a table.  There is silence between them for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shivers.  The dawn light from the skylight above has grown brighter, making the artificial light in the night club look particularly ghastly, revealing mercilessly every year of Susan's age.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In case you've never heard of how I lost all my money - and it was plenty, believe me -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last ten years have been tough on a lot of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They haven't been tough on me.  I just lost my money.  But when I compare these last ten years with the twenty I spent with him -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel kind of sorry for him, all the same -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly) Don't you think I do? (pause) You say you're going down to Xanadu?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Monday, with some of the boys from the office.  Mr. Rawlston wants the whole place photographed carefully - all that art stuff. We run a picture magazine, you know -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.  If you're smart, you'll talk to Raymond.  That's the butler. You can learn a lot from him.  He knows where the bodies are buried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what do you know?  It's morning already. (looks at him) You must come around and tell me the story of your life sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - An open door shows the pantry, which is dark.  Thompson and Raymond are at a table.  There is a pitcher of beer and a plate of sandwiches before them.  Raymond drinks a glass of beer and settles back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir - yes, sir, I knew how to handle the old man.  He was kind of queer, but I knew how to handle him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Queer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  I guess he wasn't very happy those last years - he didn't have much reason to be -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Raymond walking rapidly along corridor.  He pushes open a door. At a desk in a fairly elaborate telegraph office sits a wireless operator named Fred.  Near him at a telephone switchboard sits a female operator named Katherine (not that it matters).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fred finishes typing and then looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is the sound of the buzzer on the switchboard.  Katherine puts in a plug and answers the call.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) Mr. Charles Foster Kane announced today that Mrs. Charles Foster Kane has left Xanadu, his Florida home, under the terms of a peaceful and friendly agreement with the intention of filing suit for divorce at an early date.  Mrs. Kane said that she does not intend to return to the operatic career which she gave up a few years after her marriage, at Mr.  Kane's request. Signed, Charles Foster Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exclusive for immediate transmission.  Urgent priority all Kane papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes ... yes...  Mrs. Tinsdall - Very well. (turns to Raymond) It's the housekeeper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She says there's some sort of disturbance up in Mrs. Alexander's room.  She's afraid to go in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The housekeeper, Mrs. Tinsdall, and a couple of maids are near the door but are too afraid to be in front of it.  From inside can be heard a terrible banging and crashing.  Raymond hurries into scene, opens the door and goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane, in a truly terrible and absolutely silent rage, is literally breaking up the room - yanking pictures, hooks and all off the wall, smashing them to bits - ugly, gaudy pictures - Susie's pictures in Susie's bad taste.  Off of occasional tables, bureaus, he sweeps Susie's whorish accumulation of bric-a-brac. Raymond stands in the doorway watching him.  Kane says nothing. He continues with tremendous speed and surprising strength, still wordlessly, tearing the room to bits.  The curtains (too frilly - overly pretty) are pulled off the windows in a single gesture, and from the bookshelves he pulls down double armloads of cheap novels - discovers a half-empty bottle of liquor and dashes it across the room.  Finally he stops.  Susie's cozy little chamber is an incredible shambles all around him. He stands for a minute breathing heavily, and his eye lights on a hanging what-not in a corner which had escaped his notice. Prominent on its center shelf is the little glass ball with the snowstorm in it.  He yanks it down.  Something made of china breaks, but not the glass ball.  It bounces on the carpet and rolls to his feet, the snow in a flurry.  His eye follows it.  He stoops to pick it up - can't make it.  Raymond picks it up for him; hands it to him.  Kane takes it sheepishly - looks at it - moves painfully out of the room into the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane comes out of the door.  Mrs. Tinsdall has been joined now by a fairly sizable turnout of servants.  They move back away from Kane, staring at him.  Raymond is in the doorway behind Kane.  Kane looks at the glass ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond locks the door and comes to his side.  There is a long pause - servants staring in silence.  Kane gives the glass ball a gentle shake and starts another snowstorm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the younger servants giggles and is hushed up.  Kane shakes the ball again.  Another flurry of snow.  He watches the flakes settle - then looks up.  Finally, taking in the pack of servants and something of the situations, he puts the glass ball in his coat pocket.  He speaks very quietly to Raymond, so quietly it only seems he's talking to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slowly walks off down the corridor, the servants giving way to let him pass, and watching him as he goes.  He is an old, old man!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (without turning) Close the door, Raymond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. (he closes it)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lock it - and keep it locked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Raymond - (he is almost in a trance)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it locked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - As the dissolve completes itself, camera is travellling across the floor of the chapel past the crypts of Kane's father and mother - (marked: James Kane - 18- TO 19-; Mary Kane - 18- TO 19-;) - past a blank crypt, and then holding on the burial of Kane's son.  A group of ordinary workmen in ordinary clothes are lowering a very expensive-looking coffin into its crypt. Kane stands nearby with Raymond, looking on.  The men strain and grunt as the coffin bangs on the stone floor.  The men now place over it a long marble slab on which is cut the words:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 1907 - 1938 ONE OF THE WORKMEN Sorry, Mr. Kane, we won't be able to cement it till tommorrow.  We - Kane looks right through him.  Raymond cuts him short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men tip their hats and shuffle out of the chapel.  Kane raises his head, looks at the inscription on the wall.  It is a little to one side of Junior's grave, directly over the blank place which will be occupied by Kane himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond is now convinced that the old master is very far gone indeed - not to say off his trolley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the grave next to his son's - the grave marked "MARY KANE."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A short pause.  His eyes still on the wall, but looking through it, Kane quotes the translation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kane still stares at the wall, through it, and way beyond it. Raymond looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like poetry, Raymond?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't say, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Kane liked poetry -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not my wife - not either of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (catching on) Oh, yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking back up at the wall) Do you know what that is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more his keeper than his butler now) It's a wall you bought in China, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Persia.  It belonged to a king.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you get him to part with it, Mr. Kane?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was dead...  That's a poem.  Do you know what it means?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't, Mr. Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't used to be afraid of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The drunkeness of youth has passed like a fever, And yet I saw many things, Seeing my glory in the days of my glory, I thought my power eternal And the days of my life Fixed surely in the years But a whisper came to me From Him who dies not.  I called my tributary kings together And those who were proud rulers under me, I opened the boxes of my treasure to them, saying: "Take hills of gold, moutains of silver, And give me only one more day upon the earth." But they stood silent, Looking upon the ground; So that I died And Death came to sit upon my throne.  O sons of men You see a stranger upon the road, You call to him and he does not step.  He is your life Walking towards time, Hurrying to meet the kings of India and China. (quoting) O sons of men You are caught in the web of the world And the spider Nothing waits behind it.  Where are the men with towering hopes? They have changed places with owls, Owls who have lived in tombs And now inhabit a palace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - Thompson and Raymond.  Raymond has finished his beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson has risen.  Raymond gets to his feet and goes to the door, opening it for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond ushes Thompson into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (callously) That's the whole works, right up to date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sentimental fellow, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes and no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting to his feet) Well, thanks a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See what I mean?  He was a little gone in the head - the last couple of years, anyway - but I knew how to handle him. (rises) That "Rosebud" - that don't mean anything.  I heard him say it. He just said "Rosebud" and then he dropped that glass ball and it broke on the floor.  He didn't say anything about that, so I knew he was dead - He said all kind of things I couldn't make out.  But I knew how to take care of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can go on asking questions if you want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) We're leaving tonight.  As soon as they're through photographing the stuff -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Allow yourself plenty of time. The train stops at the Junction On signal - but they don't like to wait.  Not now.  I can remember when they'd wait all day ... if Mr. Kane said so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - The magnificent tapestries, candelabra, etc., are still there, but now several large packing cases are piled against the walls, some broken open, some shut and a number of objects, great and small, are piled pell mell all over the place.  Furniture, statues, paintings, bric-a-brac - things of obviously enormous value are standing beside a kitchen stove, an old rocking chair and other junk, among which is also an old sled, the self-same story.  Somewhere in the back, one of the vast Gothic windows of the hall is open and a light wind blows through the scene, rustling the papers. In the center of the hall, a Photographer and his Assistant are busy photographing the sundry objects.  The floor is littered with burnt-out flash bulbs.  They continue their work throughout the early part of the scene so that now and then a flash bulb goes off.  In addition to the Photographer and his Assistant, there are a Girl and Two Newspaperment - the Second and Third Men of the projection room scene - also Thompson and Raymond. The Girl and the Second Man, who wears a hat, are dancing somewhere in the back of the hall to the music of a phonograph. A flash bulb goes off.  The Photographer has just photographed a picture, obviously of great value, an Italian primitive. The Assistant consults a label on the back of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Third Newspaperman starts to jot this information down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Photographer and his Assitant start to move off with their equipment towards a large sculpture in another part of the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A flashlight bulb goes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson has opened a box and is idly playing with a handful of little pieces of cardboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thompson has turned around.  He is facing the camera for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another flash bulb goes off.  The Photographer turns to Thompson with a grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music has stopped.  The dancers have come over to Thompson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops the jigsaw pieces back into the box, looking at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up his overcoat - it has been resting on a little sled - the little sled young Charles Foster Kane hit Thatcher with at the opening of the picture.  Camera doesn't close in on this.  It just registers the sled as the newspaper people, picking up their clothes and equipment, move out of the great hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Nativity" - attributed to Donatello, acquired Florence 1921, cost 45,000 lira.  Got that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right!  Next!  Better get that statue over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think all that is worth, Mr. Thompson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Millions - if anybody wants it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The banks are out of luck, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I don't know.  They'll clear all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Venus," Fourth Century.  Acquired 1911.  Cost twenty-three thousand. Got it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patting the statue on the fanny) That's a lot of money to pay for a dame without a head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading a label) No. 483.  One desk from the estate of Mary Kane, Little Salem, Colorado.  Value $6.00.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're all set to get everything. The junk as well as the art.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a jigsaw puzzle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got a lot of those.  There's a Burmese Temple and three Spanish ceilings down the hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, all in crates.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a part of a Scotch castle over there, but we haven't bothered to unwrap it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder how they put all those pieces together?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading a label) Iron stove.  Estate of Mary Kane. Value $2.00.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it over by that statue.  It'll make a good setup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling out) Who is she anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Venus.  She always is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sure liked to collect things, didn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He went right on buying - right up to the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything and everything - he was a regular crow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: wonder -  You put all this together - the palaces and the paintings and the toys and everything - what would it spell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles Foster Kane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or Rosebud?  How about it, Jerry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the dancers) Turn that thing off, will you? It's driving me nuts!  What's Rosebud?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kane's last words, aren't they, Jerry? (to the Third Newspaperman) That was Jerry's angle, wasn't it, Jerry?  Did you ever find out what it means, Jerry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, what did you find out about him, anyway, Jerry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what have you been doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Playing with a jigsaw puzzle -   I talked to a lot of people who knew him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do they say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well - it's become a very clear picture.  He was the most honest man who ever lived, with a streak of crookedness a yard wide.  He was a liberal and a reactionary; he was tolerant - "Live and Let Live" - that was his motto.  But he had no use for anybody who disagreed with him on any point, no matter how small it was.  He was a loving husband and a good father - and both his wives left him and his son got himself killed about as shabbily as you can do it.  He had a gift for friendship such as few men have - he broke his oldest friend's heart like you'd throw away a cigarette you were through with.  Outside of that -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Rosebud?  Don't you think that explains anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't.  Not much anway. Charles Foster Kane was a man who got everything he wanted, and then lost it.  Maybe Rosebud was something he couldn't get or lost. No, I don't think it explains anything.  I don't think any word explains a man's life.  No -  I guess Rosebud is just a piece in a jigsaw puzzle - a missing piece.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'd better get along.  We'll miss the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - A large furnace, with an open door, dominates the scene.  Two laborers, with shovels, are shovelling things into the furnace. Raymond is about ten feet away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera travels to the pile that he has indicated.  It is mostly bits of broken packing cases, excelsior, etc.  The sled is on top of the pile.  As camera comes close, it shows the faded rosebud and, though the letters are faded, unmistakably the word "ROSEBUD" across it.  The laborer drops his shovel, takes the sled in his hand and throws it into the furnace.  The flames start to devour it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Throw that junk in, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue
